CREDIT GUARANTEE AND INVESTMENT FACILITY SUMMARY 
 

Establish the Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF) as a 
trust  fund  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  with  a  capital 
contribution of $130 million. 

Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Finance (finance sector development) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Regional  cooperation  and  integration 
(cross-border  infrastructure,  money  and  finance,  other  regional 
public goods)  

 

Category FI 
Category FI 
Category FI 

 
Environment:   
Involuntary Resettlement: 
Indigenous Peoples:   
 
It is proposed that CGIF be established as a trust fund of ADB with 
independent  governance  structures 
involving  a  meeting  of 
contributors,  a  board  of  directors,  and  its  own  internationally 
recruited  management  and  staff.  Draft  articles  of  agreement  and 
operational policies are in Appendixes 2 and 3, respectively. 
 
It  is  proposed  that  ADB  provide  a  capital  contribution  of  $130 
million  in  CGIF  as  part  of  the  capital  required  for  guaranteeing 
corporate local currency denominated bonds issued by investment-
grade corporations in the ASEAN+3 region.1  
 
As the first regionally owned bond guarantee agency, CGIF will be 
a trust fund of ADB, jointly owned by the governments of ASEAN+3 
and  ADB.  It  will  have  a  capital  of  $700  million,  with  $570  million 
contribution  from  the  governments  of  ASEAN+3  and  $130  million 
from ADB.  
 
The establishment of CGIF as a trust fund of ADB, together with a 
capital  contribution  from  ADB,  will  support  regional  cooperation 
within  ASEAN+3  and  promote  regional  financial  resilience  by 
allowing  investment  grade  corporations  to  gain  access  to  local 
currency  and  regional  bond  markets.  As  the  result,  CGIF  will 
reduce  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  that  currently  create 
financial fragility in ASEAN+3. 
 

(i) 

Impact.  Reduce  the  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  of 
investment grade corporations by facilitating their access to 
local  currency  bond  markets  and  thereby  reducing  the  
fragility of the financial markets in the region. 

 

(ii)  Outcome.  With  its  credit  guarantees  for  corporate  bonds,

In cooperation with ASEAN+3, ADB will establish CGIF as its trust 
fund and provide a capital contribution of $130 million. 
 
Comprehensive due diligence has been undertaken in conjunction 
with the governments of ASEAN+3. Since 2002, ADB has provided  
two  regional  technical  assistance  projects  (REG:  6127  and  6373 
ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee Mechanism, Phase 1 and Phase 2) 
to examine all elements of CGIF, including its associated risks. The 
main  risks  identified  were:  (i)  a  reputational  risk  for  ADB  resulting 
from  a  potential  conflict  of  interest  given  its  multiple  roles  and 
functions  with  regard  to  its  involvement  with  CGIF  (as  its  trustee, 
contributor,  and treasury service provider); (ii) concentrated portfolio; 
(iii) staff's capacity to assess the credit worthiness of CGIF clients 
with  international  technical  standards;  (iv)  the  credit  risk  of  the 
CGIF  portfolio;  (v)  foreign  exchange  risks,  as  CGIF  will  provide 
credit guarantees for bonds denominated in a wide range of Asian 
currencies; (vi) need for a more detailed business plan; (vii) due to 
its leverage ratio of 1 to 1, CGIF's adoption of only the country and 
currency limits until such time as when its leverage ratio or capital 
may  be  increased;  and  (viii)  there  is  no  clear  exit  strategy  and 
relatively  a  low  return  on  investment,  with  an  estimated  of  6.8% 
internal rate of return (IRR).   
 
The 
following 
risks  will  be  mitigated  by 
considerations: (i) the articles of agreement for CGIF clearly state 
the  different  roles  and  corresponding  functions  of  ADB  as  its 
trustee,  as  its  contributor,  and  as  its  treasury  service  provider.

from  those  of  ADB;  (ii)  a  dynamic  approach  will  be  adopted  to

independent  credit  judgment;  (iv)  CGIF  guarantees  will  be  provided 
only  to  issuers  with  a  minimum  investment  grade  and  CGIF  will 
maintain  a  leverage  ratio  of  1:1;  (v)    prudent  foreign  exchange 
provisioning will be put in place, based on 99% Value at Risk point

of 
guaranteed  by  CGIF;  (vi)  while  an  indicative  business  plan  has 
been prepared, a detailed  business plan and an internal risk rating 
model  will  be  developed  following  the  appointment  of  CGIF 
management and prior to commencement of guarantee operations; 
(vii)  other  prudential  limits,  in  line  with  international  best  practice 
will  be  considered  if  and  when  CGIF's  leverage  ratio  is  increased 
or  CGIF  is  recapitalized;  and  (viii)  the  IRR  of  CGIF  will  improve 
should its leverage ratio or capital be increased. CGIF's articles of 
agreement  stipulate  the  review  of  its  operations  after  each 
operational  period  of  10  years  or  earlier.  The  CGIF  board  of 
directors  will  review  its  role,  its  organizational  structure  and 
operations  to  evaluate  the  suitability  and  effectiveness  of  ongoing 
CGIF  operations,  and  based  on  the  outcome  of  each  review,  the 
meeting  of  contributors  will  determine  consequential  changes  to 
the role, organizational structure, and operations of CGIF, including 
its possible termination, as appropriate. 
 
Justifications for the formation of CGIF as a trust fund of ADB and 
for ADB's capital contribution to CGIF are as follows:  
 
Increased  access  of  investment-rated  corporations  to  local 
currency  bond  markets  and  lengthening  the  bond  maturity. 
With  CGIF  guarantees,  eligible  corporations  will  be  able  to  gain 
access to local currency debt markets and lengthen the maturity of 
their  bonds  to  meet  long-term  financing  needs  in  their  domestic 
bond  markets  and  across  the  region.  This  will  help  reduce 
corporations' dependency on short-term foreign currency loans as 
well  as  the  financial  markets'  vulnerability  to  sudden  disruption  of 
capital inflows to the region.    
 
Development  of  local  currency  and  regional  bond  markets  in 
ASEAN+3.  With  its  guarantees,  CGIF  will  help  develop  the 
domestic  and  regional  bond  markets  as  it  will  encourage  greater 
market  participation  by  issuers  in  local  currency  bond  markets.  It 
will  also  broaden  the  investor  base  by  providing  increased  credit 
protection. 
 
Enhanced regional cooperation in ASEAN+3. CGIF is a key part 
of  a  regional  initiative  that  has  been  developed  over  the  past  five

years  through  policy  dialogue  coordination  and  collaboration 
among ASEAN+3 and ADB on financial issues of common interest

initiatives.  As  CGIF  will  provide 
guarantees  for  bonds  across  the  region,  it  will  promote  the

ASEAN+3, paving the way for regional financial market integration  
 
CGIF will be implemented as an ADB trust fund and comply with all 
applicable  ADB  policies.  ADB  will  be  the  trustee  of  CGIF  and 
discharge  its  trustee  functions  through  its  Managing  Director 
General. Following commencement of CGIF guarantee operations, 
ADB's Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) will assume 
primary responsibility for administering CGIF.  

 11 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  proposed 
establishment  of  the  Credit  Guarantee  and  Investment  Facility  (CGIF)  as  a  trust  fund  of  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) with the provision of a capital contribution of $130 million. 

II.  

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

 

Economic and Regional Development Background 

 
A. 
 
2. 
One of the most valuable lessons from the Asian financial crisis of 1997–1998 was the 
need  to  develop  local  currency  bond  markets  as  an  alternative  source  of  funding  to  domestic 
and  foreign  bank  loans.  At  that  time,  bank  lending  dominated  and,  with  inadequate  hedging 
opportunities, corporations and financial institutions were highly vulnerable to foreign exchange 
risk.  Also,  since  bank  funding  was  predominantly  short  term,  long-term  investments  were 
commonly  financed  through  short-term  borrowings.  These  currency  and  maturity  mismatches 
made  domestic  balance  sheets  vulnerable  to  sudden  withdrawal  by  foreign  creditors,  which 
helped  trigger  the  crisis.  Since  then,  to  ensure  the  availability  of  long-term  domestic  currency 
funding  (and  thereby  alleviate  the  maturity  and  currency  mismatches)  and  better  channel  the 
region's  savings  into  regional  investment,  East  Asian  policy  makers  have  worked  together  to 
promote and develop local currency and regional bond markets.  

3. 
In  December  2002,  the  finance  ministers  of  members  of  the  Association  of  Southeast 
Asian  Nations  (ASEAN),  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  Japan,  and  the  Republic  of 
Korea  (ASEAN+3)  launched  the  Asian  Bond  Markets  initiative  (ABMI)  to  promote  the 
development  of  local  currency  bond  markets.  ASEAN+3  has  focused  on  policy  support  to 
expand  the  supply  of  bonds  denominated  in  Asian  currencies,  improve  credit  information  on 
debt  issuers  to  allow  better  investment  decisions,  and  help  build  market  infrastructure 
supporting  cross-border  bond  issuance  and  investment.  Another  regional  initiative  to  support 
local currency bond market development was the Asian Bond Fund, launched by Asian central 
banks through the Executives Meeting of East Asia–Pacific Central Banks in June 2003. 

To  address  some  of  the  root  causes  of  the  1997–1998  crisis,  individual  ASEAN+3 
4. 
members  have  undertaken  national  financial  sector  reform  on  their  own. 1  Reforms  have 
included  restructuring  balance  sheets  to  dispose  of  nonperforming  loans,  overhauling  bank 
ownership,  privatizing  state-owned 
financial  sector  governance, 
upgrading  macro-prudential  oversight  through  revamped  regulations  and  supervision,  and 
introducing new products and businesses.  

institutions, 

reforming 

Since 1997, local currency-denominated bonds outstanding in emerging East Asia2 have 
5. 
grown sharply from under $1 trillion in 2001 to $4.4 trillion in December 2009. However, much 
more  needs  to  be  done  to  give  corporations  better  access  to  the  region’s  bond  markets  and 
offer a variety of maturities to meet issuers’ financing needs. For example, regulators normally 
prescribe a minimum rating for bond investments for the companies they supervise—generally, 
A for banks and AA for insurance companies—or in some cases limit insurance companies to 
hold  bonds  up  to  a  certain  percentage  of  their  portfolio.  The  risk–return  properties  of  these 
markets  have  not  yet  developed  to  the  point  where  lower-rated  companies  can  sell  bonds  no 
matter  what  the  price  may  be.  Moreover,  domestic  investors  in  emerging  Asian  markets  have 

                                                 
1 In Indonesia, Philippines, and Thailand, the reforms have been notably supported by ADB 
2 ASEAN, the PRC, and the Republic of Korea. 

 2 

 

greater affinity for equities as corporate bonds are relatively new investment instruments in the 
region. 

6. 
These factors are compounded by the lack of local bond guarantee agencies to enhance 
corporations' ratings to gain full market access.3 Most guarantee agencies in the region provide 
loan  guarantees  for  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises;  however,  most  of  these  agencies 
require annual fiscal support, given the nonperforming loan rate of 2%–4% generally associated 
with this lending. Neither the skills set nor the small capitalization of such guarantee agencies 
allows them to be bona fide bond guarantee agencies. 
 
7. 
Limited  access  to  bond  markets  poses  particular  problems  for  corporations  with  long-
term financing needs—such as infrastructure companies, whose investments generally have a 
gestation of 15–20 years and whose revenues are generated in local currency. One option has 
been  bank  financing,  but  loans  seldom  extend  beyond  3  years,  posing  refinancing  risks 
throughout  the  life  of  the  project.  A  second  alternative  has  been  overseas  financing,  but  this 
entails foreign exchange risks. 
 
8. 
CGIF  aims  to  address  the  challenges  of  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  faced  by 
corporations.  It  does  so  by  providing  credit  guarantees  to  enable  them  to  raise  long-term 
funding to meet their financing needs. CGIF will make it possible for these corporations to issue 
bonds  within  their  domestic  markets  and  across  ASEAN+3.  CGIF,  consequently,  will  help 
mobilize  regional  savings  for  regional  investment  and  make  the  regional  financial  system  less 
vulnerable (Appendix 1). 
 
B. 

Background for Institutional Support  

9. 
CGIF will be one of the first regional financial entities under ASEAN+3 and will provide a 
useful model for further regional initiatives. CGIF was developed under ABMI, with ADB serving 
as  secretariat  over  the  past  7  years.  The  concept  of  CGIF  has  been  carefully  nurtured  and 
studied by ASEAN+3 members individually and cooperatively, all of whom have requested ADB 
to establish CGIF as a trust fund of ADB. 

At  the  ASEAN+3  Finance  Ministers’  Meeting  in  May  2009  in  Bali,  Indonesia,  the 
10. 
ministers  endorsed  establishing  CGIF  with  an  initial  capital  of  $500  million:  $200  million  each 
from  Japan  and  the  PRC  and  $100  million  from  the  Republic  of  Korea.  Following  further 
consultations in ASEAN, it is now expected that ASEAN members will contribute a further $70 
million  in  capital,  and  ASEAN+3  has  requested  ADB  to  contribute  $130  million.  The  capital 
contribution for CGIF is therefore expected to be $700 million. 

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy Operations  

11. 
The proposal to support CGIF as a trust fund of ADB and to contribute $130 million in 
capital supports ADB’s Strategy 20204 and is fully aligned with ADB’s regional cooperation and 
integration strategy.  

                                                 
3  A bond is considered investment grade if its credit rating is BBB– or higher by Standard & Poor’s or Baa3 or higher 
by Moody’s or BBB (low). Generally they are bonds that are judged by the rating agency as likely to meet payment 
obligations. 

4   ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020. 

Manila. 

   3

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

12. 
Enhanced regional cooperation and integration is in line with the Agreement Establishing 
the Asian Development Bank (the Charter)5 and Strategy 2020. Under Strategy 2020, ADB will 
pursue its vision and mission by focusing on three complementary strategic agendas: inclusive 
growth,  environmentally  sustainable  growth,  and  regional  integration.  In  line  with  its  new 
strategic agenda to promote greater regional integration, ADB aims to  scale up its support for 
regional cooperation and integration (RCI), increasing both the volume of its RCI operations and 
the share of RCI in total operations. In addition, under Strategy 2020, ADB clearly indicates that 
it will strengthen its support to the finance sector regionally and nationally by helping to develop 
financial  infrastructure,  institutions,  products,  and  services.  Regionally,  ADB  will  continue  to 
support  cross-border  bond  transactions.  For  the  emerging  regional  bond  market,  ADB  will 
facilitate the creation of a harmonized regulatory framework, credit guarantee mechanism, and 
regional clearing and settlement system. Through these initiatives, ADB will continue to assist in 
channeling  the  region’s  savings  into  the  most  productive  investments,  in  particular  developing 
capital  markets.  CGIF  will  operationalize  most  of  the  areas  identified  for  ADB  intervention  to 
promote regional financial sector development.   

2. 

Consistency with the Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy 

ADB's  strategy  on  regional  cooperation  and  integration  recognizes  that  different 
13. 
approaches  must  be  adopted  depending  on  circumstances. 6  The  four  pillars  of  regional 
cooperation  and  integration  are  (i) the  promotion  of  cross-border  infrastructure  and  related 
software,  (ii) trade  and  investment  cooperation,  (iii) monetary  and  financial  cooperation  and 
integration, and (iv) cooperation in promoting regional public goods. CGIF is consistent with the 
third  pillar  of  cooperation  and  integration  on  financial  cooperation  to  help  reduce  member 
countries’  poverty  through  regional  collective  action  that  develops  financial  systems  and 
strengthens macroeconomic and financial stability. CGIF fully reflects regional cooperation and 
integration  efforts  in  ASEAN+3  and  is  the  outcome  of  ADB's  support  for  these  formative 
institutional efforts. 
 

3. 

Lessons from Previous Operations 

 
14. 
In formulating the concept for CGIF, valuable lessons were drawn from the experience of 
Asian  Finance  and  Investment  Corporation  (AFIC)  and  Asian  Securitization  and  Infrastructure 
Assurance  Limited  (ASIA  Ltd)  and  that  of  international  financial  institutions  that  were  severely 
affected by the recent financial market turmoil.  

 

 

A.   AFIC 

AFIC  was  established  in  1989  in  Singapore  with  an  initial  capitalization  of  US$115 
15. 
million.  The  shareholders  comprised  ADB  (as  the  largest  shareholder)  and  25  international 
commercial banks from Asia, USA and Europe. AFIC's main objective was to provide long term 
loans  and  equity  investments  to  private  sector  medium-sized  industrial  enterprises  in  ADB's 
developing  member  countries.  However,  its  effectiveness  in  achieving  this  objective  was 
severely constrained by the following factors. 
 
16. 
AFIC  had  23  shareholders  from  a  diversity  of  economies  (Japan;  the  United  States; 
Europe;  Republic  of  Korea;  Taipei,China;  Hong  Kong,  China;  and  Singapore).  Although  ADB 

                                                 
5  ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
6 ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila. 

 4 

 

was the largest shareholder with 30% holding, it did not have veto power. AFIC operated as an 
assets booking house with a high cost of borrowing, extended loans with longer-term maturity, 
and invested in long-term assets (unquoted equity investment). Its board met on average three 
times a year but there was no hands-on approach by any of the shareholders. 
 
17.  While  the  list  of  shareholders  appeared  impressive,  many  shareholders  held  a  very 
small  stake  in  AFIC.  With  only  two  to  four  percent  stake  in  the  company,  there  was  little 
incentive for them to scrutinize project proposals. In addition, they themselves were also hit by 
the crisis and had to deal with their own problems. AFIC had a small capital base and as such 
could not be a lead institution but only a participant. Lending is an economy of scale business, 
which requires relatively cheaper funding sources, such as deposits, which AFIC did not have. 
Furthermore,  the  lending  business  needs  very  robust  risk  management,  which  like  many 
financial institutions in the region at that time, AFIC lacked. 
 
18. 
AFIC  financed  its  long-term  lending  activities  and  equity  investment  with  no  fixed 
repayments/divestments with short-term (between 3 and 5 years) and high cost borrowings.  As 
a result of the high cost of funding, AFIC had to take higher risk in lending to borrowers to have 
higher yield assets. AFIC also made small equity investments in illiquid stock markets. AFIC did 
not  make  regular  visits  to  the  accounts.  Due  to  budget  constraints,  rather  than  firsthand 
monitoring,  staff  depended  on  co-financiers  to  monitor  accounts  and  due  diligence  exercises 
was largely undertaken in house. 

B.    ASIA Ltd. 

 
Established in Singapore in 1995, ASIA Ltd. was Asia’s first regional credit guarantee 
19. 
agency with more than a commercial objective: to facilitate the development of fixed income 
markets in Asia. ASIA Ltd.'s shareholders included CapMAC Asia Ltd., Apmac Investment Pte 
Ltd.,  ADB,  Employees  Provident  Fund  of  Malaysia,  American  International  Assurance  Co. 
Ltd.,  Kookmin  Bank,  Netherlands  Development  Finance  Co.,  and  Deutsche  Investitions  and 
Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH. 

 
20. 
ASIA  Ltd.  began  with  paid-in  capital  of  $150  million  and  arranged,  guaranteed,  and 
reinsured  $2.5  billion  in  Asian  credit  over  a  2-year  period.  This  created  a  leverage  ratio  for 
ASIA  Ltd.  of  about  1:17.  It  was  rated  a  single  A  during  the  early  part  of  its  operations.  The 
Asian financial crisis, however, led to a rating agency downgrade of its claim-paying ability in 
1998. Although the Asian financial crisis of 1997–1998 hastened the demise of ASIA Ltd., it 
was not the fundamental cause, as discussed below.  
 
21. 
At  the  end  of  1999,  the  company's  $934  million  credit-insurance  portfolios  consisted 
mostly  of  sovereign,  asset-backed,  infrastructure,  and  financial  institution  debt  obligations 
throughout  Asia.  In  terms  of  geographic  distribution,  24%  of  ASIA  Ltd.'s  guarantees  and 
assumed  reinsurance  were  outstanding  to  Korea;  11.4%  to  Malaysia;  10.3%  to  Indonesia; 
9.1%  to  Hong  Kong,  China;  and  20.9%  to  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development countries other than the Republic of Korea. The downgrades of credit ratings for 
Indonesia and the Republic of Korea had flow-on effects for ASIA Ltd., requiring it to allocate 
additional  capital  at  risk  for  the  countries  downgraded  and  for  specific  guarantees.  The 
claims-paying ability of ASIA Ltd. was downgraded by Standard and Poor's (S&P) from A to 
BB. As the result, ASIA Ltd. had to stop writing new business. 

 

 
 
 
 

   5

ASIA Ltd.'s business model had fundamental flaws. It was undercapitalized with only 
22. 
$150  million,  which  was  about  half  of  the  minimum  capital  recommended  by  S&P.7 ASIA 
Ltd.’s initial rating was too low to benefit higher-rated customers or to withstand a downturn or 
the volatility typical of emerging markets.  
 
23. 
Inadequate risk management also caused difficulties for ASIA Ltd. The absence of risk-
sharing  mechanisms  with  local  financial  institutions  and  guarantee  agencies  imposed  undue 
risks  on  ASIA  Ltd.  Moreover,  some  of  ASIA  Ltd.'s  shareholders  were  focused  purely  on 
commercial  issues  and  their  own  problems  and  saw  no  need  to  contribute  additional  equity 
when  the  company  faced  a  downgrade.  ASIA  Ltd.’s  own  A  rating  limited  its  ability  to  source 
better-quality  business.  A  single  A  rating  is  insufficient  to  add  sufficient  economic  value  to 
attract a diversity of risk and support a robust business portfolio. 
 
24. 
Drawing from the lessons learned from AFIC and ASIA Ltd., CGIF has been designed 
to  achieve an  international  rating of  AAA.  Its governance  structure  is  in line  with  international 
best  practice  and,  taking  into  account  lessons  from  the  experiences  of  international  financial 
institutions  that  were  severely  affected  by  the  recent  financial  turmoil,  segregates  senior 
executives responsible for risk management from those responsible for operations.  
 
25. 
As a guarantee can be highly risky and easy to extend without a full consideration of the 
associated  risks,  the  emphasis  in  designing  the governance  structure  of  CGIF  was  to  ensure 
that  a  guarantee  cannot  be  extended  without  the  required  full  financial  due  diligence  and  the 
endorsement  from  the  chief  risk  officer  (CRO),  who  is  independent  from  the  chief  executive 
officer  (CEO),  and  the  management  of  CGIF.  In  addition,  the  board  of  CGIF  will  be  required, 
when evaluating each guarantee operation for approval, to consider the advice of an external 
advisory panel of independent experts on financial due diligence. More detailed information on 
the governance structure of CGIF is below in section III B. 
 
The financial policies of CGIF are highly prudent. CGIF will operate within the limits of 
26. 
its own available capital.8 Unless approved by the meeting of contributors, the leverage ratio of 
CGIF operations will be 1:1. Should its leverage ratio rise beyond 1:1, its liabilities in excess of 
its  capital  will  be  reinsured  to  fully  cover  any  potential  losses.  Moreover,  CGIF  will  provide 
credit guarantees only to issuers with a minimum rating that is at least investment grade. 
 
27. 
To ensure that CGIF has the capability to carry out its operations effectively, CGIF will 
adopt internationally competitive human resource policies that will allow it to attract and retain 
capable  management  and  professional.  Provisions  have  been  made  to  equip  CGIF  with 
adequate resources to meet its operating costs, in particular to undertake the risk assessment 
and monitoring of its guaranteed projects to ensure compliance with CGIF operational policies 
and relevant ADB operational policies. 
 
D. 

Development Impact 

28. 
CGIF  will  have  significant  developmental  impact  on  the  region,  as  it  will  help  reduce 
corporations’  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  and  improve  the  resilience  of  the  financial 
system in the region. The Asian financial crisis revealed the vulnerability of the region to sudden 
disruptions in the increasingly globalized financial markets. The more resilient financial system 
will  make  the  region  less  vulnerable  to  external  shocks  and  will  help  improve  financial 
intermediation between savers and investors in the region. Equally important, CGIF is a part of 

                                                 
7 Standard and Poor's. 2006. Bond Insurance Industry Overview and Analytical Focus. (29 June 29, p. 4).  
8 Available capital includes paid-in capital and retained earnings less reserves and any illiquid assets. 

 6 

 

a  key  regional  initiative  that  has  been  developed  over  the  past  5  years  through  the  policy 
dialogue, coordination, and collaboration of ASEAN+3 and ADB on financial issues of common 
interest. As such, CGIF will provide a useful model for further regional initiatives. As CGIF will 
provide  credit  guarantees  for  bonds  across  the  region,  it  will  promote  the  harmonization  of 
standards  and  practices  for  bond  issuance  in  ASEAN+3,  paving  the  way  for  regional  financial 
market integration.  

1.  

Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Alleviation 

 
 
29. 
CGIF  will  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  support  poverty  alleviation  by  making  it 
possible for investment grade corporations to gain access to their local currency bond markets 
for  financing  longer-term  investments,  notably  in  infrastructure  (Appendix  2  and  3).  Private 
corporations  will  benefit  more  than  public  corporations,  as  the  former  currently  find  it  more 
difficult to access longer-term local currency financing. These investments will finance economic 
activities  and  create  jobs.  In  addition,  the  more  resilient  financial  system  that  CGIF  aims  to 
achieve  will  help  protect  the  poor  from  the  major  setback  in  employment  that  normally  result 
from severe economic downturns caused by the collapse of financial systems (Appendix 4). As 
witnessed  during  the  Asian  financial  crisis,  the  sharp  economic  downturn  pushed  tens  of 
millions  in  the  region  below  the  poverty  line  and  reversed  overnight  the  gains  in  poverty 
reduction that had taken decades for regional economies to achieve.   
 
According to a study published in 19989, unemployment rose in the three worst-affected 
30. 
countries  by  about  5%  in  Indonesia,  about  4%  in  Thailand,  and  nearly  5%  in  the  Republic  of 
Korea  during  1997-1998.  Since  these  countries  had  enjoyed  high  growth,  low  jobless  rates, 
relatively equal income distribution, and low crime rates for decades, the sudden social distress 
was felt even more acutely. Moreover, most Asian countries had not yet developed meaningful 
social safety nets. In the same study, Lee and Rhee also demonstrated that it was the marginal 
workers—young, female, less experienced, and less educated—who were most affected by the 
crisis. They were more likely to be unemployed long term and fall below the poverty line.10 
 

2. 

Outputs and Outcome 

CGIF will establish its independent governance structures, including its own independent 
31. 
board of directors and management. An initial business plan has been prepared for CGIF. This 
will be elaborated on and finalized after CGIF has been established. This detailed business plan 
will be approved by the CGIF board of directors before the commencement of CGIF operations. 
All  projects  financed  by  bond  guarantees  will  comply  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009).  CGIF  will  use  its  capital  to  back  its  credit  guarantees  for  bonds  issued  by  investment 
grade  corporations  in  ASEAN+3  to  access  the  local  currency  bond  markets.  Once  its  $700 
million capital has been used for its guarantees, the CGIF board of directors will review its role, 
organizational  structure  and  operations  to  determine,  for  the  decision  of  its  meeting  of 
contributors, whether CGIF capital or its leverage ratio may be increased (see Appendix 1).  

32. 
The  establishment  of  CGIF  as  a  trust  fund  of  ADB  with  capital  contributions  from  ADB 
and ASEAN+3 countries will help mobilize savings to finance long-term investment domestically

A. 

Ownership 

III.  

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

33. 
The  contributors  in  CGIF  will  be  the  governments  of  ASEAN+3  and  ADB.  Ownership 
rights will be in proportion to capital contributions, with Japan providing $200 million, the PRC 
$200 million, the Republic of Korea $100 million, ASEAN countries collectively $70 million, and 
ADB $130 million. It has been agreed that, in recognition of their contributions, Japan and the 
PRC  would  have  two  seats  each  on  the  board  of  directors,  the  Republic  of  Korea  one  seat, 
ASEAN  countries  collectively  one  seat,  and  ADB  one  seat.  In  addition,  the  chief  executive 
officer (CEO) will be an ex officio member of the board. Accordingly, the board will have eight 
members, each of whom will have one vote in board deliberations. 

B. 

Governance Structure 

34. 
As  a  trust  fund  of  ADB,  CGIF  will  have  certain  obligations  and  rights.  CGIF  will  be 
required  to  follow  applicable  ADB  operational  policies  and  to  present  an  annual  activity  report 
including  audited  financial  statements  for  the  information  of  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors. 
Operating as a trust fund of ADB, CGIF will enjoy ADB’s privileges and immunities. While there 
is no financial obligation beyond the capital contribution from ADB or from any of the ASEAN+3 
countries,  there  are  significant  reputational  benefits.  In  addition,  CGIF  will  benefit  from  tax-
exempt  treatment  and  legal  protection  for  its  records  and  documents.  ADB  will  discharge  its 
trustee functions through the Managing Director General. 
 
35. 
Under its powers as trustee, ADB will delegate control of CGIF operational functions to 
the meeting of contributors. The articles of agreement (Appendix 2)11 require that a meeting of 
contributors  be  held  at  least  annually.  More  frequent  meetings  will  be  held  as  required  for 
effective decision making. 
 
In  turn,  the  meeting  of  contributors  will  delegate  routine  policy  decisions  to  the  CGIF 
36. 
board  of  directors,  which  will  consist  of  professionally  qualified  directors 12 appointed  by  the 
governments  of  ASEAN+3  and  ADB.  The  CGIF  board  will  be  headed  by  a  chairperson,  and 
there will be three important board committees for (i) internal control and risk management, (ii) 
nominations  and  remuneration,  and  (iii)  audit.  The  CGIF  board  will  approve  and  monitor 
operational  policies  and  financial  reporting  for  CGIF,  including  the  final  approval  of  all  bond 
guarantees  it  issues.  However,  day-to-day  operational  decisions  will  be  undertaken  by  the 
management of CGIF, headed by the CEO, who will provide an effective link by serving on the 
board and reporting to the board chair.  

37. 
The articles of agreement require that all board members be professionally qualified. In 
addition,  certain  members  of  the  board  committees  will  require  specific  qualifications.  For 
example,  the  chair  of  the  audit  committee  must  have  training  and  experience  in  accounting, 
auditing, and international financial reporting. The chair of the audit committee will also directly 
appoint  and  supervise  the  CGIF  internal  auditor.13  Perhaps  more  importantly,  the  chair  of  the 
internal  control  and  risk-management  committee  must  be  professionally  qualified  in  managing 
financial  risk  in  financial  institutions.  In  addition,  the  chair  of  the  internal  control  and  risk-

on operational policies are under way. 

12 As specified in the draft operational policies (Appendix 3). 

 8 

 

management  committee  will  appoint  and  supervise  the  activities  of  the  CGIF  CRO,  who  will 
chair the guarantee and investment committee at the management level.  

38. 
The governance of CGIF will be augmented by the external advisory panel, which will be 
composed  of  three  independent  experts  in  financial  sector  and  guarantee  operations.  The 
members of the panel will sit in on board and board committee deliberations without any voting 
power  and  have  access  to  board  and  management  documents  and  staff  to  ensure  full 
appreciation of the technical issues involved. Before the board makes a decision on any matter 
that are not routine, the external advisory panel will provide its independent technical advice on 
the  merits  of  the  proposal  and  recommend  acceptance  or  rejection  of  the  proposal  before  the 
board.  The  board  is  free  to  make  any  decision  it  deems  appropriate,  but,  in  cases  where  the 
decision is not in accord with the independent advice of the external advisory panel, the reasons 
must  be  stated  as  part  of  the  board  decision.  Such  cases  will  be  reported  annually  to  the 
meeting of contributors.  

39. 
CGIF  will  be  operated  in  the  best  interests  of  its  contributors,  with  its  purposes  and 
objectives  met  through  the  most  efficient  use  of  its  resources  in  an  accountable,  transparent, 
and  socially  responsible  manner.  CGIF  will  be  operated  strictly  on  commercial  grounds  to 
ensure its financial viability and the maintenance of its AAA rating.

2. 

Corporate Governance 

46. 
Corporate  governance  will  be  under  the  direction  of  the  CEO  and  the  executive 
committee. Membership in the executive committee will initially be determined by the board of 
directors.  All  CGIF  activities  will  be  governed  by  CGIF  operational  policies  (Appendix  3).  The 
initial  operational  policies  will  be  approved  by  the  meeting  of  contributors  but  subsequent 
revisions or additions must be proposed by the executive committee and approved by the board 
of directors.  
 
47. 
There  will  be  two  important  exceptions  to  the  control  of  the  CEO  and  the  executive 
committee  over  corporate  governance.  The  first  exception  is  that  the  internal  and  external 
auditors  will  report  directly  to  the  chair  of  the  audit  committee  and  be  under  her/his  functional 
control  (though  administratively  reporting  to  the  CEO).  The  second  exception  is  that  the  CRO 
will  report  directly  to  the  chair  of  the  internal  control  and  risk  management  committee  and  be 
under her/his functional control (though administratively reporting to the CEO). While the CEO 
and the vice-president of operations will be in charge of developing guarantee proposals in line 
with  the  operational  policies,  the  CRO  and  the  guarantee  and  investment  committee  will  be 
responsible  for  determining  that  the  risk  inherent  in  each  guarantee  proposal  is  acceptable 
before the proposal can be considered by the CGIF board of directors. 
 
 
 
48. 
CGIF’s strategy defines the long-term goals of CGIF and the operational approaches for 
achieving  them.  These  goals  and  operational  approaches  will  be  reflected  in  the  detailed 
business  plan  that  will  be  prepared  by  the  CEO  in  consultation  with  the  executive  committee. 
This plan and the CGIF credit rating methodology will be approved by the CGIF board prior to 
undertaking  any  guarantee  operations.  CGIF  management  will  then  be  responsible  for 
implementing  the  business  plan,  with  the  board  monitoring  compliance  with  it.  If  there  are 
difficulties  in  meeting  objectives  of  the  business  plan,  management  will  inform  the  board  as 
soon as possible. This will enable the board to recommend or take appropriate corrective action. 
 

CGIF Long-Term Strategy and Business Plan 

3. 

4. 

Financial Policies 

 
49. 
CGIF  will  be  financed  solely  from  capital  contributed  by  member  countries  and  ADB. 
CGIF will not borrow from any source to finance its operations except for the purposes of cash 
management.  For  example,  it  may  well  be  advantageous  to  use  short-term  borrowing  rather 
than liquidate an investment position to meet a call on a guarantee or another CGIF operational 
requirement. Allowing borrowing for cash management is not intended to create net liability but 
simply supply liquidity.  
 
The aggregate amount of contingent liabilities that may be assumed by CGIF at any time 
50. 
by the issuance of guarantees outstanding will not exceed the total paid in capital of CGIF plus 
retained  earnings,  less  provisions  for  credit  and  foreign  exchange  losses  and  all  illiquid 
investments.  The  meeting  of  contributors,  with  a  recommendation  from  the  board  of  directors, 
may approve leverage above 1:1, as appropriate, provided that the excess over the total paid in 
capital  of  CGIF  plus  retained  earnings,  less  provisions  and  all  illiquid  investments  made  by 
CGIF,  are  reinsured.  A  detailed  counterparty  risk  policy,  including  a  minimum  rating  for  re-
insurers, will be included in the CGIF risk management framework. 
 
51. 
The CGIF guarantee fee will be market-based and will reflect the risk of the underlying 
credit  CGIF  is  guaranteeing.  The  benefit  of  the  CGIF  guarantee  is  measured  in  terms  of  the 
reduced  interest  rate  cost  associated  with  the  upgraded  bond  issue.  The  benefit  will  be

negotiated with the issuer, and will be at least commensurate to the underlying credit risk of the 
bonds to be guaranteed by CGIF and will meet CGIF's criteria of a minimum return on capital.14 
 
General  guarantee  loss  provisions  refer  to  "ex-ante"  provisions  related  to  future 
52. 
uncertain  events.  For  purposes  of  determining  an  appropriate  level  of  general  provisions, 
guarantees  are  equivalent 
the  CGIF  portfolio  will  be  necessarily 
concentrated, general guarantee loss provisioning will be set in line with the internally generated 
bond ratings mapped to international ratings so that the probability of default on each bond and 
the  entire  portfolio  can  be  fully  assessed  and  adequately  provisioned.    During  its  initial 
operations, CGIF will obtain a bilateral rating from a reputable international credit rating agency 
to verify and assist CGIF's independent credit judgment of its potential clients and for its credit 
loss  provisioning  until  such  that  time  that  the  consistency  of  its  internal  ratings  with  that  of 
international ratings is established. In addition, CGIF management will make specific provisions 
for  any  guarantee  at  risk  on  a  case-by-case  basis  based  on  the  ongoing  monitoring  of  all 
guarantees outstanding.  
 
53. 
CGIF guarantee operations involve the issuance of guarantees for local currency bonds 
denominated most  commonly in  one of the currencies of the ASEAN+3 countries (US dollars 
might also be used by some of these countries for bond guarantees but that would present no 
contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  for  CGIF  as  its  functional  currency  is  the  US  dollar). 
Nevertheless,  CGIF  will  be  exposed  to  considerable  currency  risk  as  it  will  guarantee  bonds 
denominated in a wide range of Asian currencies. To ensure that CGIF leverage ratio is within 
1:1, a marked to market value adjustment of its guarantees will be undertaken weekly.  
 
54. 
The  contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  can  be  significant  over  the  period  that  the  local 
currency  bonds  are  expected  to  be  outstanding.15  In  the  absence  of  market  instruments  to 
hedge  contingent  foreign  exchange  risks,  CGIF's  initial  contingent  foreign  exchange  risk 
provisioning will be prudently determined based on the 99% value at risk point of local currency 
movement for individual bond guaranteed by CGIF based on the historical volatilities of foreign 
exchange forwards or the implied volatilities of foreign exchange options with tenors of at least 1 
year. Since the volatilities can increase significantly in times of market stress, either a buffer will 
be  applied  to  these  results  or  the  highest  volatilities  from  the  entire  period  for  which  data  are 
available will be used. The foreign exchange provisioning will take into account the maturity of 
the  individual  bonds  guaranteed  by  CGIF.  The  determination  of  the  foreign  exchange 
provisioning will be made annually; however, in case of a higher than expected depreciation of 
the US dollar, CGIF will set aside additional provisioning to ensure that CGIF is able to maintain 
its 1:1 leverage ratio.  This foreign exchange provisioning will be separate from the credit loss 
provisioning.

costs  in  the  isolated  situations  where  OTC  solutions  could  be  made  available.  As  a  result,  commonly  accepted 
market  practices  in  Asia  do  not  include  the  use  of  options  to  cover  contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  and,  as  a 
result,  the  reserves  for  contingent  foreign  exchange  losses  will  be  set  in  line  with  the  volatility  of  the  currency  of 
denomination of the guarantee extended. 

 12 

 

5. 

Risk Management 

55. 
CGIF’s  external  auditor  will  be  appointed  by  the  meeting  of  contributors  upon  the 
recommendation of the board of directors, based on the consideration of the audit committee. 
Both the internal and the external auditors will report on all functional issues to the chair of the 
audit  committee.  The  CRO  will  likewise  be  appointed  by  the  meeting  of  contributors  upon  the 
recommendation of the board of directors, which is based in turn on the recommendation of the 
internal  control  and  risk  management  committee.  Auditing,  reporting,  and  operational  risk 
management  will  be  functionally  independent  of  management.  As  these  individuals  will  not 
participate  in  corporate  bonuses,  they  will  be  financially  independent  of  the  volumes  of 
guarantees  extended.  Under  the  corporate  governance  structure  of  CGIF,  the  CRO  will  have 
final authority to endorse a guarantee proposal to the board for its consideration. 
 
56. 
The  other  important  governance  safeguard  is  that  salaries  will  be  internationally 
competitive.  A  top-ranked,  internationally  qualified  staff  is  essential  for  successful  CGIF 
operation.  Bonuses  will  be  paid  to  CGIF  staff  from  a  pool  equal  to  10%  of  CGIF  profits.  The 
distribution of the bonus pool will be based strictly on merit. However, bonuses will not be paid 
until the bonds guaranteed in that year have been fully repaid without any calls. Should there be 
any calls on CGIF guarantees issued in that year, the bonus pool will take the first loss. 
 
The  CRO  will  prepare  and  present  a  CGIF  policy  on  the  management  of  risk  (risk 
57. 
management  framework)  for  CGIF,  following  approval  by  the  board  of  directors.  This  policy 
together with the detailed business plan and internal risk rating model will be formulated for the 
early consideration and adoption of the internal control and risk management committee of the 
board  of  directors.  This  policy  and  the  detailed  business  plan  must  be  adopted  prior  to  the 
guarantee and investment committee’s consideration of CGIF guarantees. The following are the 
guiding principles for the risk management framework.

using international technical standards.

6. 

Prudential Safeguards 

 
There  are  a  number  of  key  prudential  safeguards  that  will  be  incorporated  in  CGIF's 
59. 
operational policies. The prudential limits ensure that CGIF will not become unduly exposed to 
individual country risks, industries, industrial groups, or individual issuers. The country exposure 
limit of 20% of CGIF capital will ensure that smaller countries have access to CGIF guarantees 
and that its portfolio will be appropriately diversified. However, to minimize the currency risk for 
the  CGIF  portfolio,  a  currency  limit  on  its  operations  will  be  set  at  40%  of  its  capital.13 The 
industry limit, based upon S&P classification, will be limited to 30% of the country limit, while the 
individual  issuer  will  be  limited  to  12%  of  the  country  limit.  However,  the  limited  size  of  CGIF 

                                                 
13 This limit  would allow, for example, a Japanese corporation to issue bonds denominated in Thai baht. While this 
guarantee would be charged to the Japan country quota, it could double the potential issuance in baht from 20% to 
40%. 

 14 

 

capital requires that single issuer, group exposure, and sector limits be waived until such time 
as the CGIF leverage ratio is raised or its capital is increased. 
 

7. 

Management of Capital Resources 

Business Overview and Strategy 

 
60. 
Payment  for  the  shares  subscribed  by  the  contributors  will  be  received  by  the  trustee 
and  deposited  by  ADB  for  CGIF.  The  trustee  will  invest  this  account  in  money  market 
instruments  in  line  with  ADB  policies  until  the  CGIF  board  and  management  have  been 
appointed.  
 
61. 
The  primary  objective  in  the  management  of  CGIF's  capital  resources  is  to  protect  the 
principal by maintaining a prudent exposure to market, credit and liquidity risks. Liquidity must 
always be available to meet potential calls on guarantees issued so that all investments should 
be marketable within a reasonable timeframe. Within the constraints determined by this primary 
objective, CGIF will strive to maximize returns on the invested asset portfolio while minimizing 
the volatility of investment income. To this end, CGIF capital resources will be placed with the 
ADB  Treasury  Department  to  manage  at  a  fee  of  10  basis  points.  Once  CGIF  is  established, 
CGIF  management  will  discuss  with  ADB  specific  investment  strategies  and  performance 
benchmarks for the CGIF board of directors approval. The agreed investment strategies will be 
in  line  with  ADB  risk  management  policies  and  investment  guidelines  and  in  line  with  the 
maturities  of  CGIF's  specific  guarantee  operations,  as  well  as  with  CGIF  financial  policies  as 
reflected in the operational policies and articles of agreement.  
 
C. 
 
62. 
A demand study for guarantees covering Cambodia, PRC, Indonesia, Republic of Korea, 
Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam was conducted in the last quarter of 
2008.14 In each country, interviews were conducted with market regulators and others such as 
security  and  exchange  agencies,  central  banks,  ministries  of  finance,  local  credit-rating  and 
bond-pricing agencies, investment banks, and institutional investors. The objective of the study 
was  to  determine  the  kinds  of  potential  issuers  and  their  potential  volumes  of  issuance.  The 
focus  was  on  general  corporate  issuers,  securitization  issues,  and  other  potentially  long-term 
financial  requirements  such  as  for  infrastructure  and  other  public–private  partnerships.  The 
study showed that there were no local institutions providing third-party guarantees for local bond 
issues,  though  some  supranationals  like  ADB  provided  guarantees  in  some  cases. 15  Most 
market  participants  fully  endorsed  the  proposal  to  establish  CGIF  in  order  to  encourage 
investment-grade corporations to issue bonds denominated in local currency.    
 
63. 
The  study  determined  that  the  issuers  most  likely  to  benefit  from  the  establishment  of 
CGIF would be those rated between BBB and A (see Appendix 6 for an explanation of common 
ratings).16 Because of common prudential regulations, banks can generally invest only in bonds 
rated A, while insurance and pension plans can invest only in bonds rated AA. However, issues 
of bonds rated AA or even AAA will also benefit from CGIF as its guarantees will enable them to 
extend their bond maturities and/or issue bonds outside their domestic markets. There did not 
appear  to  be  strong  demand  for  securitization  issues.  Expectations  were  that  opportunities 
might  arise  with  respect  to  residential  mortgages;  however,  the  timing  is  uncertain.  For  long-

local currency rating agencies.

term financing such as for infrastructure, demand is high, and there is abundant demand from 
insurance  companies,  banks,  and  other  investors  for  well-structured  infrastructure  paper.  To 
estimate  the  demand,  a  bottom–up  approach  was  used  wherein  demand  estimates  were 
constructed  from  assumptions  involving  the  basic  building  blocks,  such  as  the  number  of 
potential issuers currently excluded and the size of their likely issues. 
 
64. 
As  the  demand  study  for  corporate  guarantees  assumed  that  CGIF  would  not  be  fully 
operational  until  2011,  demand  estimates  begin  that  year.  As  shown  in  the  table,  the 
conservative estimate of demand for CGIF guarantees amounts to $3.5 billion in 2011 and rises 
to $4.7 billion in the 5 years to 2016, for a compound annual growth rate of 6%. For the future 
years  included  to  make  up  a  10-year  financial  forecast  period,  the  demand  growth  rate  in  the 
2017–2020 period was assumed to be 5%. For this longer period, if CGIF is able to meet this 
conservative estimate of demands for bond guarantees, the guarantees extended would amount 
to over $24 billion.

D. 
 

Financial Performance 

1. 

Projected Financials 

 
65. 
The  financial  analysis  covers  2011–2020  based  on  the  demand  study  baseline.  The 
financial analysis for CGIF is shown in Appendix 5 with the base case shown in Table A5.1. It 
shows  an  initial  capital  of  $700  million  for  2011,  augmented  in  succeeding  years  by  retained 
earnings.  No  recapitalization  has  been  assumed,  and  the  final  capital  in  2020  is  projected  to 
amount to $858 million based on the initial capital and retained earnings.  
 

 16 

 

The  estimated  demand  for  bond  guarantees  rises  from  $3,470  million  in  2011  to 
66. 
$5,652 million  in  2020.17 In  this  base  case  scenario,  the  assumption  is no  use  of  leverage.  As 
shown in Appendix 5, Table A5.1, CGIF will extend $100 million of guarantees per annum in the 
years from 2011 to 2013 and, thereafter, $150 million per annum until 2020.The leverage ratio 
will  be  kept  well  below  1:1,  rising  from  0.14  in  2011  to  0.87  in  2020.  Based  upon  these 
assumptions,  the  pilot  CGIF  will  be  able  to  meet  3%  of  the  estimated  cumulative  demand  for 
bond guarantees throughout 2011–2020. 
 
Under  the  base  case  scenario,  the  principal  income  items  as  shown  in  Table  A5.2  are 
67. 
interest  income  on  the  $700  million  capital  (an  assumed  return  of  1.6%  per  annum  with 
investments in US Treasuries with an average maturity of 3–5 years) and guarantee fees that 
are assumed to amount to 150 basis points on total guarantees of $100 million. Together with 
upfront guarantee fees, the total income in 2011 is estimated to be $13.0 million. 
 
68. 
Principal expenses include staff costs that, based upon the initial skills mix and 23 staff 
positions, will amount to $5.5 million. Facility leasing, board of director expenses, credit rating 
costs, and other expenses are estimated at another $3.3 million, for a total cost of $8.8 million in 
2011. Net income in 2011 is projected to be $4.2 million, rising to over $26 million in later years. 
The internal rate of return (IRR) for the entire period is estimated to be 6.8%, almost double the 
return on the equivalently rated 10-year US Treasury bond of about 3.8%. 
 

2. 

Financial Resilience 

69. 
It  is  expected  that  CGIF  will  maintain  financial  viability  under  stringent  stress  tests  as 
shown in Appendix 5. For example, a simulated 10% portfolio failure rate in 2016 (Table A5.3) 
due  to  an  economic  dislocation  in  one  economy  would  lead  to  an  estimated  loss  of  over  $44 
million in 2016 (Table A5.4), and reduce the IRR to 5.8% from 6.8% in the base case.  
 
A much more stringent depression stress test is structured along the lines of the Bond 
70. 
Insurance Capital Adequacy Model proposed by S&P for bond issuers like CGIF. 18 As shown in 
Tables A5.5 and A5.6, the depression is assumed to be deep, with 5% default loss in each of 
the  4  years  of  the  depression,  more  than  double  the  maximum  default  rates  that  actually 
occurred during the Great Depression.19 Additionally, during the simulated depression years of 
2014–2017, no new guarantee business was assumed to have been written, and, while no cuts 
were  made  in  staff  strength,  the  returns  on  invested  capital  were  appropriately  reduced.  With 
these  depression-oriented  conditions,  CGIF  had  substantial  losses  during  these  years,  albeit 
declining in magnitude. The IRR for the entire period was nonetheless positive at 4.8%, down 
from  6.8%  in  the  base  case.  The  CGIF  financial  structure  is  resilient  to  these  potential  major 
shocks. 
 
E. 

Unique Public–Private Structure 

71. 
CGIF will be established as a trust fund of ADB with capital contributions from ASEAN+3 
governments  and  ADB.  CGIF  has  the  public  purpose  of  creating  regional  public  goods  in  the 
form of enhanced financial resilience in ASEAN+3. The operations of CGIF will be conducted on 
commercial terms. They will assist those corporations in ASEAN+3 with a minimum investment

currency  and  maturity  mismatches.  The  public  goods  nature  of  CGIF  will  ensure  that  it  fully

the gradual fostering of market segments in the local currency bond markets that are currently 
absent (Appendix 7). 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

ADB Assistance and Transaction Structure 

A. 
 
72. 
The proposed ADB assistance has two principal components: (i) establishing CGIF as a 
trust  fund  of  ADB  and  (ii)  providing  to  CGIF  a  capital  contribution  of  $130  million,  which  will 
represent over 18% of CGIF’s total capital. The proposed trust fund and the capital contribution 
are fully consistent with ADB policies and both have open-ended timeframes.  There  is  no  exit 
strategy for the proposed CGIF investment except for its eventual closure and the distribution of 
capital  and  retained  earnings  to  its  ASEAN+3  contributors  and  ADB.  However,  after  each 
operational period of no more than 10 years, the board of directors will review the role of CGIF, 
its  organizational  structure,  and  its  operations  to  evaluate  their  suitability  and  effectiveness. 
Based on the outcome of each review and the recommendations of the board of directors, the 
meeting  of  contributors  will  consider  and  determine  changes  to  the  role,  organizational 
structure, and operations of CGIF, including its termination, as appropriate. 
 
B. 
 
73. 
CGIF  is  an  integral  part  of  policy  actions  to  promote  the  development  of  the  bond 
markets  supported  under  ABMI.  Establishing  CGIF  as  a  trust  fund  of  ADB  will  considerably 
shorten  its  set-up  time.  If  not  as  a  trust  fund  of  ADB,  CGIF's  establishment  would  involve  a 
lengthy  process  requiring  ASEAN+3  legislative  bodies  to  accept  the  articles  of  agreement.  In 
the  meantime,  the  continued  financial  fragility  arising  from  residual  currency  and  maturity 
mismatches could endanger financial stability in the region, as they appeared to do during the 
recent  international  financial  crisis.  The  proposed  ADB  capital  contribution  responds  to  an 
ASEAN+3 request for that level of contribution and will serve as a useful catalyst to accelerate 
CGIF  guarantee  operations.  Lastly,  ADB’s  strong  performance  record  in  managing  its  own 
investment  resources  means  that  ADB  will  bring  expertise  in  this  area  to  directly  benefit  its 
member countries’ regional cooperation. 
 
C. 
 
74. 
Comprehensive due diligence has been undertaken in conjunction with the governments 
of ASEAN+3 since 2002 supported by two regional technical assistance projects from ADB, to 
examine  all  elements  of  CGIF,  including  its  associated  risks.  The  main  risks  of  the  proposed 
capital contribution and its mitigation measures are as follows: 
 

Risks and Mitigation Measures 

(i)  Conflict  of  interest.  As ADB will be the trustee, contributor, and treasury service 
provider of CGIF, these roles and functions combined could cause potential conflict 
of interest and pose a reputational risk for ADB.  To mitigate any potential conflict of 
interest  and  protect  ADB's  reputation,  the  articles  of  agreement  for  CGIF  clearly 
state  the  specific  functions  of  each  role  that  ADB  will  undertake.  These  roles  and 
functions  have  been  fully  discussed  and  agreed  with  among  ASEAN+3  and  ADB. 
Moreover,  CGIF will have its own governance structure and operations—including 

 18 

 

its  own  meeting  of  contributors,  board  of  directors,  management  and  staff—
separate from those of ADB. 

 
(ii)  Concentrated  portfolio.    With  an  initial  paid-up  capital  of  $700  million,  CGIF  will 
be  able  to  guarantee  no  more  than  10  issuers  and  as  such  will  likely  have  a  
concentrated portfolio, heightened by its focus on the ASEAN+3 region.  Although 
this risk can be partly mitigated by provisioning for credit loss and foreign exchange 
risk, in the event of a sharp economic slow down in the region that could lead to its 
possible downgrade, CGIF will ensure to operate within the leverage ratio of 1:1.        

 
(iii)  Capacity of CGIF staff to apply international technical standards to its clients.  
CGIF  staff  will  rate  its  potential  clients  by  applying  ''international  technical 
standards''  to  assess  their  credit  worthiness  to  ensure  that  its  selected  clients  will 
have a minimum BBB rating using the international technical standards. However, 
given that CGIF will be newly established, its staff's capacity to rate its clients will 
be  untested.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  for  each  guarantee  transaction  considered  by 
CGIF,  it  will  obtain  a  bilateral  rating  from  one  of  the  reputable  international  rating 
agencies to assist in its decision on its guarantees.  

 
(iv)  Credit risk of the guarantee portfolio. To mitigate the risk of CGIF's concentrated 
portfolio, it will adopt a dynamic approach to determine the required guarantee loss 
provisioning based on the credit quality and rating of its portfolio. Each guarantee 
will be reviewed annually, and, in the event of any credit deterioration of its clients, 
additional provisions will be set aside.  Moreover, CGIF will closely monitor issuers 
whose ratings are expected to fall below the international investment grade (BBB). 

 
(v)  Currency risk. CGIF will be exposed to considerable currency risk as it will provide 
credit  guarantees  to  bonds  denominated  in  a  wide  range  of  Asian  currencies.  To 
ensure  that  the  leverage  ratio  of  CGIF  is  maintained  at  1:1,  a  marked-to-market 
value  adjustment  of  its  guarantees  will  be  conducted  weekly.    Given  the  lack  of 
other  mitigation  measures  for  this  risk,  the  initial  contingency  foreign  exchange 
provisioning  will  be  prudently  calculated  based  on  the  99%  value  at  risk  point  of 
local currency movements (for individual bond guarantees) taking into account the 
maturity  of  the  guaranteed  bonds.    The  determination  of  the  provisioning  will  be 
made annually, and in case of a higher than expected depreciation of the US dollar, 
CGIF  will  set  aside  additional  provisioning  to  ensure  that  CGIF  maintains  its  1:1 
leverage ratio.    

 
(vi)  Lack of a detailed business plan.  An indicative business plan has been prepared 
for  CGIF. 20  However,  as  CGIF  management  has  yet  to  be  appointed,  a  more 
detailed business plan and an internal risk rating model will be developed upon the 
appointment  of  CGIF  management  and  prior  to  CGIF's  commencement  of  its 
guarantee operations.      

 
(vii)  Incomplete prudential limits.  During the pilot operations of CGIF (i.e. during the 
period  of  the  initial  capitalization  of  US$700  million),  there  will  essentially  be  two 
prudential  limits  in  place--country  and  currency  limits.  However,  other  prudential 
limits such as those for sector, single issuer, and group exposure will be considered 
for adoption in line with international best practice if and when its leverage ratio or 
capital is increased.  

                                                 
20 Supplemental Appendix B. 

   19

 
(viii) Lack of exit strategy and relatively low return on investment.  Given the unique 
nature  of  CGIF's  policy  mandate,  its  articles  of  agreement  do  not  have  an  explicit 
exit strategy but stipulate the review of its operations after each operational period 
of  10  years  or  earlier.  CGIF's  board  of  directors  will  review  its  role,  organizational 
structure  and  operations  to  evaluate  the  suitability  and  effectiveness  of  ongoing 
CGIF operations. Based on the outcome of each review, the meeting of contributors 
will  consider  and  determine  consequential  changes  to  the  role,  organizational 
structure and operations of CGIF, including its possible termination, as appropriate. 
Moreover, if and when CGIF's leverage ratio or capital is increased, its internal rate 
of return would improve from the current estimate of 6.8%. 

 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

Environment and Social Safeguards 

A. 
 
CGIF  will  comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  the  applicable 
75. 
environmental  and  social  safeguard  requirements  of  concerned  ASEAN+3  governments 
(Appendix  8).  It  will  adopt  and  implement  an  environmental  and  social  management  system 
(ESMS)  that  adheres  to  these  environmental  and  social  safeguard  requirements.21 CGIF  will 
adopt an ESMS in conformity with ADB's ESMS framework prior to its first guarantee operations 
(Appendix 8). The environmental and social safeguard review procedure described in the ESMS 
will  be  integrated  into  CGIF's  due  diligence,  appraisal,  approval,  and  monitoring  procedures. 
CGIF  will  assign  staff  with  the  necessary  safeguard  capacity,  qualifications  and  experience  to 
develop and implement the ESMS. It will designate the guarantee and investment committee as 
the decision-making and reviewing authority for the ESMS. CGIF will prepare an annual report, 
with  respect  to  guarantees  extended,  summarizing  the  following:  (i)  performance  of  clients  in 
implementing  the  safeguard  plans  (EMP,  resettlement  plan  or  IPDP)  and  compliance  with 
applicable government laws and regulations, and ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement; (ii) areas 
of noncompliance arising during safeguard plan implementation, corrective measures adopted, 
and outstanding issues requiring follow-up actions, if any; and (iii) findings from periodic reviews 
of the ESMS, and recommendations for improvement. 
 
B. 

 Implementation Arrangements 

 

76. 
CGIF  will  report  annually  with  fully  audited  financial  statements  through  its  board  of 
directors at its meeting of contributors. These reports, prepared in compliance with international 
reporting standards, will also serve CGIF’s reporting requirements as a trust fund of ADB.  
 
77. 
CGIF will undertake an annual credit-rating review to ensure the maintenance of its AAA 
credit  rating.  To  help  ensure  that  the  ongoing  business  of  CGIF  is  healthy,  each  guarantee 
extended by CGIF will be closely monitored to ensure that corrective action is taken should it be 
found to be at risk.  
 
Although there is no specific financial target for CGIF, it must maintain its AAA rating and 
78. 
be  financially  healthy  to  ensure  its  continued  effectiveness  in  meeting  its  public  policy 
objectives. The appropriate financial target for CGIF will be based on a minimum rate of return 
for each guarantee. This requires that CGIF must not extend a guarantee if the return is not at 

                                                 
21 See CGIF Operational Policies, Environment and Social Management System Framework, pp. 100–103 (Appendix 

3). 

 20 

 

Anticorruption Policy 

least  commensurate  with  the  underlying  credit  risk  of  the  bond  and  meet  at  least  CGIF's 
criterion of a minimum return on capital. 
  
79. 
The primary responsibility for monitoring and meeting CGIF’s responsibilities rests with 
the CEO, reporting through the board of directors to the meeting of contributors. However, that 
responsibility  is  shared  with  (i)  the  CRO,  regarding  financial  risks  and  in  respect  of  the 
environmental  and  social  safeguards;  (ii)  the  internal  auditor,  regarding  accounting,  auditing, 
and  financial  reporting  standards;  and  (iii)  the  oversight  committees  of  the  CGIF  board  of 
directors, namely the internal control and risk-management committee and the audit committee. 
The  overall  responsibility  for  monitoring  CGIF  performance  and  the  performance  of  the  CEO 
rests with the board, which is responsible for recruiting and dismissing the CEO, in consultation 
with the meeting of contributors. 
 
C. 
 
80. 
CGIF will fully comply with ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and 
Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003),  as  detailed  in  CGIF 
operational  policies  (Appendix  3).  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  CGIF  will  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal 
procedures  and  controls  following  international  best  practices  to  prevent  corruption,  money 
laundering and the financing of terrorism.  
 
D. 
 
The  proposed  capital  contribution  by  ADB  of  $130 million  will  be  less  than  ADB’s 
81. 
maximum limit of 25% of the total committed capital, but will exceed the single exposure limit of 
$75 million.22 However,  the  proposed  contribution  is  considered  to  be  appropriate  given  the 
commitments  of  ASEAN+3  and  the  unique  and  important  role  CGIF  will  play  in  reducing 
financial fragility in the region. 
 
E.  
 
The  proposed  capital  contribution  by  ADB  is  an  ‘equity  investment’  for  purposes  of 
82. 
Article  11  of  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank.  Even  though  equity 
investments  are  to  be  processed  by  PSOD, 23 CGIF  has  been  processed  by  OREI.  CGIF  is  a 
unique  regional  initiative  that  arose  out  of  the  on-going  ABMI  work  of  OREI,  and  involves 
ongoing  policy  dialogue  and  close  cooperation  to  promote  regional  economic  and  financial 
integration among ASEAN+3 member countries. The issues involved therefore differ from those 
for  a  typical  non-sovereign  equity  investment.  OREI  has  had  primary  responsibility  for 
processing  CGIF  but  has  been  working  closely  with  other  departments  including  PSOD. 
Following  commencement  of  CGIF  guarantee  operations,  PSOD  will  assume  primary 
responsibility for administering CGIF.

ARTICLES OF AGREEMENT 

 

OF  

CREDIT GUARANTEE AND INVESTMENT FACILITY 

The  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  comprising  Brunei  Darussalam,  Cambodia, 
Indonesia,  Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic,  Malaysia,  Myanmar,  Philippines, 
Singapore,  Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam,  plus  the  People's  Republic  of  China,  Japan,  and 
Republic  of  Korea  established  the  Asian  Bond  Markets  Initiative  to  develop  and 
strengthen  the  local  currency  and  regional  bond  markets  to  promote  economic  growth 
and  financial  development  and  to  prevent  disruptions  to  the  international  financial  order 
so as to allow the use of Asian savings within the region. 

In  furtherance  of  that  objective,  these  countries  together  with  the  Asian  Development 
Bank    desire  to  establish  the  Credit  Guarantee  and  Investment  Facility  to  provide  credit 
enhancement  and  make  investments  to  allow  eligible  issuers  to  access  local  currency 
bond markets and thereby avoid currency and maturity mismatches by issuing within the 
region. 

 
(C)  Each  country,  wholly-owned  entity,  and  ADB  listed  in  Schedule  1,  pursuant  to  the 
Instrument of Acceptance (substantially in the form set out in Schedule 2)  deposited with 
the  trustee  of  CGIF,  have  adopted  the  following  Articles  of  Agreement,  for  the 
establishment  and  operation  of  CGIF.  In  the  case  of  such  wholly-owned  entity,  the 
country concerned has also provided assurances satisfactory to the trustee regarding the 
operation of CGIF.  

1. 

DEFINITIONS 

Unless the context otherwise requires, the several terms defined in Schedule 3 to these 
Articles of Agreement have the respective meanings therein set forth, and shall apply as if 
they were defined herein.  

2.  OBJECTIVES AND FUNCTIONS OF CGIF  

2.1. 

Objectives 

The  objectives  of  CGIF  are  to  promote  economic  development,  to  promote  resilience  of 
the  financial  markets,  and  to  prevent  disruptions  to  the  international  financial  order,  by 
developing  deep  and  liquid  local  currency  and  regional  bond  markets.  This  will  result  in 
efficient  allocation  of  Asian  savings  within  the  region  by  facilitating  access  by  entities 
rated investment-grade  to such markets while promoting the issuance of debt securities 
with longer-term maturities to match the gestation of investment projects. 
 
2.2. 

Functions 

The following development functions of CGIF are to be undertaken on commercial terms 
within the ASEAN+3 countries: 

 
(A) 

 
(B) 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 28          Appendix 2 
Appendix 2 
 

 2 

2.2.1.  guaranteeing bonds that are denominated in local currencies and issued 
by  entities  rated  Investment  Grade  in  such  a  manner  as  to  reduce 
currency and maturity mismatches; 

 
2.2.2.  guaranteeing bonds that are not denominated in local currencies issued 
by  entities  rated  Investment  Grade;  provided  the  entities  concerned  are 
naturally hedged in such currency;  

 
2.2.3.  making  investments  for  development  of  the  bond  markets;  provided    no 
such  investments  shall  be  made  until  after  the  Meeting  of  Contributors 
shall have determined that CGIF is in a position to commence such type 
of operations; and 

 
2.2.4.  undertaking  such  other  activities  and  providing  such  other  services 
consistent with its objectives (including appropriate substitute credit rating 
arrangements  for  Brunei  Darussalam  and  the  new  ASEAN  member 
countries of Cambodia, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Myanmar and 
Viet Nam). 

 

 

CGIF shall not borrow from any source to finance its operations described in Article 2.2 
except for the purposes of cash management.  
 

2.3. 

No Borrowing 

3. 

ESTABLISHMENT 

3.1. 

Establishment 

3.1.1.  The Board of Directors of ADB has approved the establishment of CGIF, 
and its administration by ADB as the Trustee, in each case in accordance 
with  these  Articles  of  Agreement.  The  operations  of  CGIF  shall  be 
financed  solely  from  funds  that  are  contributed  from  time  to  time  in 
accordance  with  the  provisions  of  these  Articles  of  Agreement,  and  any 
other CGIF property. 

 
3.1.2.  ADB in its capacity as the Trustee shall: 

(a)  hold in trust all CGIF funds and other property; 
 
(b)  manage and use CGIF funds and other property only for the 

purposes of and in accordance with the provisions of these Articles 
of Agreement; and 

 
(c) 

subject to the provisions of these Articles of Agreement, appoint 
and terminate all Executive Staff, professional staff  and consultants 
of CGIF. 

3.2 

Trust Only 

It  is  the  intention  of  these  Articles  of  Agreement  to  establish  and  define  only  the 
relationship of trustee and beneficiary between the Trustee and each Contributor.

CAPITAL AND SHARES 

4. 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

5. 

4.1   The  authorized  capital  of  CGIF  shall  be  US$[700,000,000],  divided  into  [7000] 
Shares  with  a  nominal  value  of  US$100,000  each.  All  such  Shares  shall  be 
subscribed and fully paid in by the Contributors.   

 
4.2    The authorized capital of CGIF may be increased by an affirmative vote of at least 
two-thirds of the number of existing Contributors who hold collectively at least two-
thirds of the total outstanding Shares. 

 
4.3  The holder of each Share shall have the following rights: 

a.  as to voting: the right to receive notice of, attend and vote as a Contributor at any 

Meeting of Contributors;  

b.  as  to  income:  the  right  to  receive  income,  profit  and  other  distributions  as 

provided for in these Articles of Agreement; and 

c.  as  to  capital:  the  right,  in  a  winding-up  of  CGIF,  to  repayment  of  capital  as 

provided for in these Articles of Agreement. 

4.4   Each Share subscribed for by a Contributor shall be allocated to such Contributor 

only   after full payment has been received by the Trustee. 

 
4.5    None  of  the  Shares  or  capital  in  CGIF  may  be  pledged  or  encumbered  in  any 

manner whatsoever.

LIMITS ON OPERATIONS 

6.1   Limits on Contingent Liabilities and Leverage 

The  level  of  contingent  liabilities  to  be  assumed  by  CGIF  will  be  determined  by  the 
Meeting of Contributors on the recommendation of the Board of Directors based upon an 
affirmative  vote  of  at  least  two-thirds  of  the  number  of  existing  Contributors  who  hold 
collectively  at  least  two-thirds  of  the  total  outstanding  Shares.  However,  where  the 
leverage ratio exceeds 1:1, the contingent liabilities in excess of the sum of total paid in 
capital  plus  retained  earnings  less  reserves  and  all  illiquid  investments  made  by  CGIF 
must  be  reinsured  and  CGIF  will  seek  reinsurance  to  cover  such  excess  contingent 
liabilities

7.2.3 At  the  Organizational  Meeting,  the  Contributors  shall  (i)  determine  the 
selection  process  for  appointment  of  the  chairperson  of  the  Meetings  of 
Contributors; (ii) elect the first members of the Board of Directors, who have 
been nominated in accordance with the requirements set forth in Article 8.3, 
except  the  Chief  Executive  Officer;  (iii)  approve  the  first  set  of  the  CGIF 
Operational Policies; (iv) delegate specific powers to the Board of Directors 
pursuant to Article 10.3.2; (v) approve the initial terms of reference and the 
establishment  of  each  of  the  Audit  Committee,  Internal  Control  and  Risk 
Management  Committee,  and  Nomination  and  Remuneration  Committee; 
and  (vi)  undertake  all  other  actions  considered  necessary  for  CGIF  to 
commence  operations.  Solely  for  the  purposes  of  this  Article  7.2.3,  and

Notices of Meetings 

7.5.1 Unless  otherwise  waived  by  the  intended  recipient,  the  Trustee  or  the

of  a  Special  Meeting)  prior  written  notice  of  the  forthcoming  Meeting  of 
Contributors,  the  agenda  and  all  related  materials.    The  notice  shall  state 
the  place,  date  and  time  of  the  meeting  and,  in  the  case  of  a  Special 
Meeting, the purpose or purposes for which the Special Meeting is called.
