A. 

CGIF Nomination and Remuneration Committee 

148.  The  performance  of  a  company  is  strongly  determined  by  the  quality  of  its  employees,  
CGIF,  therefore,  needs to  be  able  to  attract  and  retain  the  best  qualified  professionals.  It  also 
needs  to  ensure  that  incentive  systems  motivate  and  elicit  best  effort  from  management  and 
also  align  their  interests  with  those  of  Contributors  to  ensure  that  they  operate  in  the  best 
interests of Contributors and other stakeholders. 
 
149.  The role of the Nomination and Remuneration Committee is to provide CGIF’s Board of 
Directors with a formal, transparent and effective mechanism for the selection and remuneration 
of the best qualified senior executives in a competitive manner.  
 
150. 
In  most  companies,  a  separate  Remuneration  Committee  is  established  alongside  the 
Nomination Committee and tasked with the determination of incentive policies and schemes for 
senior  executives.  However,  given  the  likely  staff  size,  CGIF  will  have  a  joint  Nomination  and 
Remuneration Committee. 
 
151.  The Nomination and Remuneration Committee will have three Board members including 
the Chairperson of the Board of Directors and the ADB Board member. 
 
152.  The Nomination and Remuneration Committee reports to the Board of Directors and has 
no executive powers, although it has the full power of the Board in terms of approving specific  
remuneration  packages  for  senior  executives.  A  member  of  the  External  Advisory  Panel  may 
also attend Committee meetings. 
 
153. 
Its main responsibility is to identify and select, through due process and in a transparent 
and competitive manner, the best qualified candidates for senior executive positions namely the 
CEO, the CRO (in cooperation with the Internal Control and Risk Management Committee), and 
the  Internal  Auditor  (in  cooperation  with  the  Audit  committee)  and  to  determine  their 
remuneration  and  related  terms  and  conditions  in  line  with  internationally  competitive 
benchmarks for comparable positions.  The Nomination and Remuneration Committee submits 
its report and recommendations to the Board for review and approval. 
 

1.   Nominations 

 

 The Nomination and Remuneration Committee is empowered, and given the resources, 
154. 
to seek the services of an internationally qualified professional recruitment agency or consultant, 
in identifying potential candidates. This provides the Committee with access to a wide choice of 
possible  qualified  candidates  and  provides  assurance  to  the  Board  and  Contributors  that  a 
thorough, competitive and professional process has been used in the selection process. If CGIF 
decides to use consultants, then the Committee will choose the consultants. 
 
155.  The Nomination and Remuneration Committee is also empowered to consult, and where 
appropriate, co-opt representatives of the Trustee and Contributors as non-voting members of 
the Committee to assist it in its selection process. 
 

 82        Appendix 3

156.  Potential  candidates  are  provided  with  sufficient  information  about  CGIF  and  the  rights 
and  responsibilities  of  Board  members  to  enable  them  to  gain  an  understanding  of  their 
expected  role.  Selected  candidates  have  the  opportunity  to  meet  with  all  existing  Board 
members.  Members  of  the  Board,  after  having  met  with  a  candidate,  may  express  any 
reservations in confidence to the chairperson of the Nomination and Remuneration Committee. 
The final decision to make an offer takes place after a discussion by the Board of Directors upon 
the Nomination and Remuneration Committee’s recommendations. 
 
157.  Other duties of the Committee include the following: 
 

(i)  Have plans in place for the succession of the Chairperson and the CEO; 

 

(ii)  Make  the  necessary  recommendations  to  the  Board  for  the  continuation 
in  service  of  executive  staff  of  CGIF  in  so  far  as  the  selection  and 
appointment  of 
these  management  executives  are  responsibilities

CGIF’s annual report; and 

(iv)  Ensure  that  the  Chairperson  of  the  Nomination  and  Remuneration 
Committee attends the Meeting of Contributors fully prepared to respond 
to any questions from Contributors relating to the nomination and election 
of the CEO.

D.  Terms of Reference for the External Advisory Panel 

166.  CGIF  is  involved  in  activities  that  are  inherently  risky.  In  such  circumstances  it  is 
important  that  the  Board  of  Directors  has  access  to  advice  that  is  objective  and  based  on  a 
sound understanding of corporate finance, international financial administration, bond issuance, 
bond  guarantees  and  bond  markets.  The  role  of  the  External  Advisory  Panel  is  therefore  to 
provide  specialized  technical  inputs  to  enable  the  Board  of  Directors  to  understand  the 
complexities  and  risks  associated  with  particular  decisions. The  External  Advisory  Panel  is  an 
important resource for the Board of Directors. 

 Appendix 3 

85 

 
167.  The External Advisory Panel is expected to render an independent and unbiased opinion 
on  all  non-routine  matters  considered  by  the  Board  of  Directors  and  its  Committees  (routine 
matters  are,  by  contrast,  decisions  concerning  office  facilities,  secretarial  support  and 
meeting/agenda issues). These opinions are detailed and in writing. If the Board of Directors or 
its  Committees  make  a  decision  that  is  at  variance  with  the  course  proposed  by  the  External 
Advisory Panel they are required to provide a written justification for their decision. A record of 
these  advisory  opinions  relative  to  the  actual  decisions  of  the  Board  and  its  Committees  is 
included in the CGIF Annual Report that is provided to the Meeting of Contributors.  
 
168.  Members of the External Advisory Panel are entitled to attend all meetings of the Board 
of Directors and its Committees, Management Committee Meetings and Meeting of Contributors 
as observers. The Chairperson of the Board of Directors and the CEO are required to inform the 
External Advisory Panel members of all such meetings and to provide them with a copy of the 
documentation for the meeting participants. For meetings where the External Advisory Panel is 
required  to  provide  advisory  views  on  the  topics  for  decision,  copies  of  the  meeting 
documentation  must  be  provided  to  the  External  Advisory  Panel  well  in  advance  so  that  the 
Panel has the opportunity to do the necessary analysis and follow-up consultations that may be 
required with CGIF staff and outside experts. The resulting opinion from the External Advisory 
Panel  is  included  in  the  meeting  documents  for  participants’  consideration.  The  External 
Advisory Panel must also be copied on all management and Board reports and on background 
analysis or information prepared for management or the Board. 
 
169.  The  External  Advisory  Panel  of  the  Board  of  Directors  provides  specialist  guidance  to 
Committees  of  the  Board  and  to  the  Board  as  a  whole.  Minutes  and  decisions  of  those 
Committees and of the Board as a whole includes the guidance and recommendations provided 
by  the  External  Advisory  Panel  and  in  cases  where  the  recommendations  of  the  External 
Advisory Panel are not adopted, the Committee or the Board as a whole gives the reasons why 
the recommendations have not been adopted. 
 
170.  The External Advisory Panel assignments are not full time positions, but at certain times 
full time attention to agenda items will be required in order not to delay CGIF decision making. 
External Advisory Panel members are therefore required to compile a log of the time spent on 
CGIF activities so that appropriate compensation can be made. The Chairperson of the External 
Advisory  Panel  is  expected  to  certify  these  records  from  the  other  External  Advisory  Panel 
members and the Chairperson of the Board of Directors is required to: 
 

(i) 

certify  the  inputs  record  from  the  Chairperson  of  the  External  Advisory 
Panel; 
 

(ii)  authorize  CGIF  consulting  payments  for  all  services  provided  by  the 

External Advisory Panel; and 

 
(iii)  authorize  payments  for  outside  experts  that  the  Advisory  Panel  may  need 
to consult to ensure international best practices in all CGIF operations. 

 
171.  The External Advisory Panel members are highly qualified consultants appointed by the 
Meeting  of  Contributors  as  proposed  by  the  Trustee  and  reporting  to  the  Chairperson  of  the 
Board  of  Directors  and  to  the  Meeting  of  Contributors.  They  must  have  the  following 
qualifications and experience:

III.  Managerial  Decision-Making in CGIF 

A.  Chief Executive Officer 

173.  The  CEO  is  responsible  for  day-to-day  operations  of  CGIF.    The  CEO  is  appointed  by 
the Trustee after the Meeting of Contributors has approved the recommended candidate of the 
Board  of  Directors.  Under  the  strategic  guidance  of  the  Board,  the  CEO  has  full  authority  to 
operate  and  manage  CGIF  under  the  mandates,  financial  targets,  parameters  of  risk 
management, annual budgets and business plans as approved by the Board of Directors. (see 
Appendix 1 for the  organizational structure of CGIF). 
 
B.  Management Committees 
 
174.  There are two management committees that assist in managing CGIF: 
 

the  Executive  Committee  which  is  chaired  by  the  CEO,  meets  weekly  to 
decide on all non-routine operational matters. The size and composition of 
the  Executive  Committee  is  determined  by  the  Board  of  Directors,  its 
members  appointed  by  the  Trustee  upon  the  Board’s  recommendation 
(after  taking  account  of  suggestions  from  the  Board’s  Nomination  and 
Remuneration Committee).  

ii.  the Guarantee and Investment Committee, which is chaired by the CRO, is 
responsible  for  assessing  and  managing  risk  associated  with  CGIF 
operations.  The  size  and  composition  of  the  Guarantee  and  Investment 
Committee is determined by the Board of Directors, its members appointed 
by  the  Trustee  upon  the  Board’s  recommendation  (after  taking  account  of 
the suggestions from of the Board’s Internal Control and Risk Management 
Committee).  

i. 

 

 

175.  The decisions of the Executive Committee and Guarantee and Investement Committee 
are on a consensus basis. 
 
176.  To ensure that risk management and control are operationally independent of business 
management,  the  CRO  reports  directly  to  the  Chairperson  of  the  Board’s  Internal  Control  and 
Risk  Management  Committee  on  proposed  bond  guarantees  and  associated  investment  risks, 
and to the CEO on day-to-day operations and administrative matters. 
 
177.  Prior to the approval of the first guarantee, the Board of Directors must have considered 
and approved a detailed Business Plan and internal rating system for CGIF. Once a guarantee 
has  been  identified  for  an  ASEAN+3  corporation  and  endorsed  by  the  CEO  for  further 
consideration, the Guarantee and Investment Committee screens guarantees (and investments) 
to control overall risk. It approves guarantee and investment proposals for consideration of the 
Board  of  Directors.  In  the  initial  phase  of  CGIF  operations,  all  guarantee  proposals  must  be 
approved by the Board of Directors 

 

178.  CGIF  management  executives  including  the  Vice  President  of  Operations,  CFO,  and 
General  Counsel  may  serve  on  both  the  Executive  Committee  and  the  Guarantee  and 
Investment  Committee.  Other  functional  or  specialized  committees  may  be  created  at  the

executive  level  when  appropriate  and  as  determined  by  the  Board  of  Directors  in  conjunction 
with the CEO. 
 
 
C.  External and Internal Auditors   
 
179. 
 CGIF’s  External  Auditor  is  appointed  by  the  Meeting  of  Contributors  and  must  be  an 
internationally recognized firm of good repute upon the recommendation of the Audit Committee 
of the Board of Directors. Both the Internal and External Auditors report to the Chairperson of 
the  Board’s  Audit  Committee.  The  External  Auditor  liaises  with  the  Internal  Auditor  and  Chief 
Accountant to ensure that accounting systems employed effectively meet all international audit 
and reporting standards. 
 
D.  Reporting Relationships 
 
180.  All  CGIF  executives  except  the  CRO  and  Internal  Auditor  report  directly  to  and  are 
functionally  responsible to the CEO. All CGIF executives are administratively responsible to the 
CEO.

IV.  Financial Policies 

No Borrowing 

Fund Contributions 

A. 
 
181.  The  operation  of  CGIF  is  financed  solely  from  funds  contributed  by  member  countries 
and ADB. Any surplus for a preceding fiscal year is allocated to CGIF’s reserves, provided that if 
determined  by  the  Meeting  of  Contributors,  an  appropriate  amount  of  surplus  is  distributed  to 
shareholders.  No  Contributor  has  the  right  to  receive  any  distributions  from  CGIF  except  as 
provided in the AoA. 
 
B. 
 
182. 
CGIF will not borrow from any source to finance its operations except for the purposes of 
cash  management.  For  example  it  may  well  be  advantageous  to  use  short  term  borrowing  as 
opposed to liquidating an investment position to meet the cash need for a call on a guarantee or 
any other CGIF operational requirements. The consideration for borrowing for purposes of cash 
management  is  not  intended  to  create  a  net  liability  position  but  simply  to  supply  the  needed 
liquidity. 
 
C. 

Limits on Contingent Liabilities and Leverage 

 Guarantee Fees 

183.  The aggregate amount of contingent liabilities that may be assumed by CGIF at any time 
by the issuance of guarantees outstanding shall not exceed the total paid in capital of CGIF plus 
retained earnings less reserves, less all illiquid investments. 
 
184.  The aggregate amount of contingent liabilities that may be assumed by CGIF at any time 
by the issuance of guarantees outstanding shall not exceed the total paid in capital of CGIF plus 
retained  earnings,  less  provisions  for  credit  and  foreign  exchange  losses  and  all  illiquid 
investments. The Meeting of Contributors, with a recommendation from the Board of Directors, 
may approve leverage above 1:1, as appropriate, provided that the excess over the total paid in 
capital  of  CGIF  plus  retained  earnings,  less  provisions  and  all  illiquid  investments  made  by 
CGIF,  are  reinsured.  A  detailed  counterparty  risk  policy,  including  a  minimum  rating  for  re-
insurers, will be included in the CGIF risk management framework. 
 
D. 
 
185.  CGIF guarantee fee is market based and reflects the risk of the underlying credit CGIF is 
guaranteeing. The benefit of the CGIF guarantee is measured in terms of the reduced interest 
rate  cost  associated  with  the  upgraded  bond  issue.  The  benefit  is  assessed  with  the  full 
involvement of the issuer and the guarantee fee for CGIF is negotiated with the issuer, at least 
commensurating  to  the  underlying  credit  risk  of  the  bonds  to  be  guaranteed  by  CGIF  and 
meeting CGIF's criteria of a minimum return on capital. 
 
E. 
 
186.  No  contributor  is  liable,  by  reason  of  its  participation  in  CGIF,  for  any  obligations  of 
CGIF, including any obligations to pay under the guarantees. Under the AoA, the liability of each 
Contributor is limited to the unpaid portion of the Shares it has subscribed that has become due 
and payable. 

Limitation of Liability 

 90        Appendix 3 
 

Appendix 3 

Foreign exchange policy 

 
F. 
 
187.  As CGIF is not authorized to borrow for its operations, other than for fully covered money 
market operations, no foreign exchange exposures are envisaged to arise from debt operations.  
 
188.  CGIF guarantee operations involve the issuance of guarantees for local currency bonds 
denominated most  commonly in one of the currencies of the ASEAN+3 countries (U.S. dollars 
might also be used by some of these countries for bond guarantees but that would present no 
contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  for  CGIF  as  its  functional  currency  is  the  U.S.  dollar). 
Nevertheless, CGIF will be exposed to considerable currency risk due as it will guarantee bonds 
denominated in a wide range of Asian currencies. To ensure that CGIF leverage ratio is within 
1:1, a marked to market value adjustment of its guarantees will be undertaken weekly. 
 
189. 
 The contingent foreign exchange risks can be significant over the period that the local 
currency bonds are expected to be outstanding.9 In the absence of market instruments to hedge 
contingent  foreign  exchange  risks,  CGIF's  initial  contingent  foreign  exchange  risk  provisioning 
will be prudently determined based on the 99% Value at Risk point of local currency movement  
for individual bond guaranteed by CGIF based on the historical volatilities of foreign exchange 
options with tenors of at least 1 year. Since the volatilities can increase significantly in times of 
market stress, either a buffer will be applied to these results or the highest volatilities from the 
entire period will be used. The foreign exchange provisioning will take into account the maturity 
of  the  individual  bonds  guaranteed  by  CGIF.    The  determination  of  the  foreign  exchange 
provisioning will be made annually, however, in case of a higher than expected depreciation of 
the US dollar, additional provisions will be considered to ensure that CGIF could maintain its 1:1 
leverage ratio.  This foreign exchange provision is separate from the credit loss provisioning.  
 
190.  The guarantee fees will be upfront and charged in U.S. dollars or in local currency. The 
fees  charged  in  local  currency  will  be  immediately  converted  into  U.S.  dollars.  Local  currency 
contingent  risks  are  also  constrained  by  the  country  limit  of  20%  for  bond  guarantees  issued. 
U.S.  dollars  will  likely  be  the  non-local  currency  of  choice  and  that  currency  will  not  involve 
currency risks for CGIF since the CGIF functional currency is the U.S. dollar. Other currencies 
are not likely to present meaningful risks for CGIF as prior to CGIF accepting non-local currency 
as the denomination for the bond and the guarantee, the corporation  will have to satisfy CGIF 
that it had a natural hedge in that currency, i.e. was earning revenues in that currency to repay 
the bond obligation. 
 
 

                                                 
9 Using the survey demand for the expected currency denomination of the local currency bonds (Demand Study for 
CGIF,  January  2009),  the  distribution  of  guarantees  in  ASEAN+3  currencies  would  have  meant  that  those 
contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  over  the  historical  five-year  periods  from  1975  to  2005  would  have  resulted  in 
gains/losses  between -0.29% and +0.264%  during these five-year periods, assuming that 1.0% of the guarantees 
are  called.  This  is  much  higher  than  the  0.27%  deferred  rates  expressed  on  BBB  rated  bonds  as  calculated  by 
Moody's from 1920-2009. While such contingent foreign exchange risks can theoretically be covered by long dated 
options, such options are not generally available in Asia due to a combination of factors associated with exchange 
controls,  the  lack  of  suitable  counterparties,  inadequate  maturities  on  the  available  swap  rates  and  the  very  high 
costs  in  the  isolated  situations  where  OTC  solutions  could  be  made  available.  As  a  result,  commonly  accepted 
market  practices  in  Asia  do  not  include  the  use  of  options  to  cover  contingent  foreign  exchange  risks  and,  as  a 
result,  the  reserves  for  contingent  foreign  exchange  losses  will  be  set  in  line  with  the  volatility  of  the  currency  of 
denomination of the guarantee extended.

V.  Prudential Limits 

191.  The  prudential  limits  for  CGIF  are  modeled  on  ADB’s  prudential  limits  for  its  non-
sovereign  portfolio,  that  is,  its  loans,  equity  investments  and  guarantees  are  not  subject  to 
counter-guarantees from Government. Prudential limits include the (i) country exposure limit, (ii) 
industry exposure limit, (iii) group exposure limit, and (iv) single exposure limit. These proposed 
prudential limits are intended to ensure that CGIF’s portfolio of guarantees is well diversified and 
less prone to large unexpected losses than would be the case if it were concentrated in a few 
countries or industries or confined to a few large borrowers or groups. 

 

192.  The  development  of  the  CGIF  portfolio  will  be  undertaken  on  a  gradual  basis  from 
smaller  sized  bond  guarantees  up  to  larger  sized  guarantees  to  ensure  that  even  in  the 
beginning  phases  of  CGIF,  the  portfolio  of  risks  will  be  as  diversified  as  possible.  This  same 
approach  will  be  applied  to  the  length  of  bond  maturities  that  CGIF  guarantees  will  a  gradual 
lengthening  of  bond  maturities  to  3  to  5  years,  again  to  ensure  reduced  risk  and  increased 
diversification.  This  gradual  approach  is  particularly  important  in  the  initial  stages  of  CGIF’s 
portfolio  development  because  as  is  noted  below,  certain  prudential  limits  such  as  industry, 
single and group exposures cannot be applied within country limits in early CGIF operations, 
 
A. 

Country Exposure Limits 

193.  Country  exposure  limits  are  set  by  multilateral  development  banks  (MDBs)  to  balance 
two considerations: (i) equitable access by clients and (ii) concentration of risks in the portfolio. 
In line with the tradeoffs as assessed by ADB, the country limit for CGIF is 20% of its capital. 
This will ensure access by smaller countries and that the portfolio is appropriately diversified.10 
In  the  case of  an  ASEAN+3  corporation  requesting  a  CGIF  guarantee  for  issuance  in  another 
ASEAN+3 country, the country quota used is assigned to the nationality of the corporate issuer, 
even if locally incorporated in the issuing country. In light of this arrangement, the currency limit 
for CGIF is set at 40% of its paid in capital.  

 

 

B. 

Industry Exposure Limits 

Industry limits are intended to reduce CGIF’s exposure to factors common to industries 
194. 
such  as  demand  fluctuations,  input  costs  for  needed  commodities,  regulatory  changes  and 
financial contagion. 
 
195.  CGIF  guarantees  are  not  counter-guaranteed  by  the  concerned  Governments  of  the 
ASEAN+3 countries. Without Government counter-guarantees, the entire credit risk and country 
risks  are  borne  by  CGIF.  The  principal  risk  for  CGIF's  guarantees  can  be  expected  to  be 
associated with the industrial and individual corporate credit risks. 

196.  The sector classifications that are used by CGIF to monitor industrial concentration are 
as follows: 
 

(i)  Agriculture and primary products 
 
(ii)  Aerospace/automobile/capital goods/metal

198.  Each  guarantee  extended  by  CGIF  is  classified  according  to  its  industrial  sector  in

is increased or the maximum leverage ratio is raised by the Meeting of Contributors.   

C. 

Single and Group Exposure Limits  

199.  Single exposure limits are intended to ensure that CGIF’s portfolio of guarantees is not 
concentrated  on  a  few  large  recipients  and  that  CGIF’s  portfolio  risks  are  more  diversified.  To 
the extent that client’s risks are uncorrelated, overall portfolio risk is thereby reduced. The norm 
for single exposure limit is 12% of the country limit. The group exposure limit is proposed to be 
30% the country limit. (Both single issuer and group exposure limit will be waived until such time 
that  CGIF’s  capital  is  increased  or  the  maximum  leverage  ratio  is  raised  by  the  Meeting  of 
Contributors).

200.  The  proposed  single  and  group  exposure  limits  need  to  be  graduated  with  the 
introduction  of  a  risk  rating  system.    With  such  a  system,  it  would  be  possible  to  base  the 
revised limits on the risk-adjusted size of the proposed guarantees. This will result in the single 
customer investment limit being smaller, the higher the risk of loss. The CRO develops such a 
risk  rating  system  and  introduces  it  following  Board  approval  within  the  first  year  of  CGIF’s 
operations. 
 
201. 
In  this  assessment  of  customer  risk,  it  is  important  to  assess  the  client’s  ability  and 
willingness  to  offer  appropriate  levels  of  security  for  the  proposed  CGIF  guarantee.  Other 
expected covenants relate to limitations on additional borrowing and the demonstration that the 
bond  proceeds  resulting  from  CGIF  guarantee  must  be  used  in  financing  the  intended 
investments  with  the  expected  results  in  terms  of  capacity  augmentation,  for  example,  being 
realized.  Guarantees  fully  backed  by  liens  on  corporate  assets  justify  even  lower  risks.  In 
performing  risk  analysis,  all  indicators  of  financial  deterioration  will  be  taken  into  account,  not 
just  historical  records  of  the  concerned  industry  itself.  Risk  analysis  will  not  be  confined  to 
historical data, no matter the length of that data series. 
 
D. 

General Guarantee Loss Provisioning 

 

202.  General  guarantee  loss  provisions  refer  to  "ex-ante"  provisions  related  to  future 
uncertain  events.  For  purposes  of  determining  an  appropriate  level  of  general  provisions, 
guarantees  are  equivalent  to  loans.  As  general  guarantee  loss  provisioning  varies  over  the 
business cycle with higher guarantee loss provisions during the expansionary phase of the cycle 
and lower guarantee loss provision during the contractionary phase. Because the CGIF portfolio 
will be necessarily concentrated, general guarantee loss provisioning will be set in line with the 
internally  generated  bond  ratings  mapped  to  international  ratings  so  that  the  probability  of 
default on each bond and the entire portfolio can be fully assessed and adequately provisioned.  
During  its  initial  operations,  CGIF  will  obtain  a  bilateral  rating  from  a  reputable  international 
credit  rating  agency  to  verify  and  assist  CGIF's  independent  credit  judgment  of  its  potential 
clients  and  for  its  credit  loss  provisioning  until  such  that  time  that  consistency  of  its  internal 
ratings  with  that  of  international  ratings  are  established.    In  addition,  CGIF  management  will 
make specific provisions for any guarantee at risk on case by case basis based on the ongoing 
monitoring of all guarantee outstanding.

VI.  Management of Capital Resources 

A.  Payment of Contributions 

203.  Payment  for  the  shares  subscribed  by  the  Contributors  is  received  by  the  Trustee  and 
deposited in an ADB account for CGIF.24 The Trustee initially manages these accounts based 
upon  ADB  investment  policies  but  once  the  CGIF  Board  is  constituted,  these  funds  will  be 
managed  in  accordance  with  the  strategies  of  CGIF  management  as  approved  by  the  CGIF 
Board of Directors. 
 
B. 

Objective 

Currency of Denomination of Investments 

204.  The  primary  objective  in  the  management  of  CGIF's  capital  resources  is  to  protect  the 
principal  by  maintaining  a  conservative  exposure  to  the  market,  credit  and  liquidity  risks. 
Liquidity must always be available to meet potential calls on the guarantees issued so that all 
investments should be marketable within a reasonable time. Within the constraints determined 
by this primary objective, CGIF strives to maximize returns on the invested asset portfolio while 
minimizing the volatility of investment income. Based on this objective, CGIF capital resources 
are placed with ADB Treasury Department to manage at a fee as agreed between the Board of 
Directors and ADB. Once CGIF is established, CGIF will discuss with ADB specific investment 
strategies and performance benchmarksfor the CGIF Board of Directors approval. The agreed 
investment  strategies  will  be  in  line  with  ADB  risk  management  policies  and  investment 
guidelines  and  in  line  with  the  maturities  of  CGIF’s  specific  guarantee  operations  and  CGIF 
financial policies (as reflected in the AoA and the Operational Policies). 
 
C. 
 
205.  As  the  functional  currency  of  CGIF  is  the  U.S.  dollar  and  CGIF's  capital  has  been 
subscribed  in  U.S.  dollars,  all  investments  are  either  denominated  in  U.S.  dollars  or  hedged 
back  into  U.S.  dollars  through  derivatives  contracted  in  conjunction  with  any  non  U.S.  dollar 
denominated  investments.  Derivatives  are  used  only  to  hedge  identified  risks  in  the  portfolio 
(such  as  foreign  exchange  risk)  and  not  to  expose  the  portfolio  to  greater  risk  than  would  be 
typical under a strategy utilizing only cash securities. All counterparty risks associated with any 
such derivatives will be monitored and counterparties will be limited to those with credit ratings 
of at least A for short term obligations.

guidelines:

which there would be minimal market price changes when sold.

original investment was in non-U.S. dollars; and

all  long  term  instruments,  i.e.  those  over  one  year  must  be  rated  at  least  AA,  by  international 
credit rating agencies. 

 

E.  Performance Reporting  and Communication 
 
210.  At  the  end  of  each  month,  the  CFO  reconciles  accounting  transaction  and  asset 
summary  data  with  the  Treasury  Department  of  ADB,  and  resolves  any  discrepancies  and 
advises the CEO and the CRO of such discrepancies.  
 
211. 
In  addition,  on  a  monthly  basis,  the  CFO:  (i)  submits  to  the  CEO  and  the  CRO  a 
comprehensive monthly review statement setting forth information on investment performance, 
both  net  and  gross  of  management  fees;  a  summary  of  holdings  and  a  listing  of  all  securities 
held  at  market  value;  additions  to  and  withdrawals  from  the  portfolio;  as  well  as  such  data  as 
may  be  requested  in  respect  to  the  portfolio,  including,  without  limitation,  the  rating,  yield, 
maturity,  effective  duration;  and  (ii)  certifies  to  the  CEO  and  the  CRO  compliance  with  the 
investment instructions, as defined above, and the accuracy of the reconciliation of its records 
with  the  Custodian,  noting  any  deviations.  Copies  of  these  reports  are  also  made  available  to 
the Board. 
 
212.  The CFO is required to report to the CEO and the CRO any time the portfolio's exposure 
to  a  source  of  risk  differs  significantly  from  expectations.  If  the  CFO  becomes  aware  of  any 
violation of these guidelines, the CFO must immediately report to both the CEO and the CRO 
and if possible, take immediate actions to return to compliance or propose in consultation with 
the CRO, a strategy for returning to compliance for the approval of the CEO.  
 
H.  Amendment of Investment Guidelines 
 
213.  These  investment  guidelines  will  be  revised  from  time  to  time  to  reflect  changing 
circumstances and any proposed changes will be agreed and signed off by CEO, CFO and the 
CRO  for  submission  to  the  Board.  If  approved,  the  proposed  amendment  will  then  be 
implemented by the CFO.

VII. 

 Guarantee Risk Management System 

214.  The  CRO  will  prepare  a  CGIF  policy  on  the  management  of  guarantee  risks  (risk 
management  framework)  for  its  guarantees.  This  policy  together  with  the  detailed  business 
pland and internal risk rating model will be formulated for the early consideration and adoption 
of the Internal Control and Risk Management Committee of the Board of Directors. This policy 
together with the detailed business plan and internal risk rating model must be adopted prior to 
the  consideration  of  guarantees  for  Board  approval  by  the  Guarantee  and  Investment 
Committee  at  the  management  level.  The  following  are  the  guiding  principles  for  the  risk 
management framework: 
 

Prior to guarantee consideration by the CGIF Board of Directors: 

Corporate bond issuers must have a minimum of investment grade credit rating 
(BBB) on a credit rating scale using international technical standards in order to 
be  considered  for  a  CGIF  bond  guarantee.  Both  the  quantitative  and  qualitative 
data  for  each  corporation  will  be  used  as  inputs  to  CGIF's  internal  credit  rating 
model  to  arrive  at  the  risk  rating  of  the  concerned  corporation  to  confirm  that  it 
meets the minimum rating of BBB using international technical standards; 
CGIF  will  undertake  a  full  financial  due  diligence  of  the  concerned  corporate 
entity  and  its  proposed  bond  issue  and  where  substantial  financial  risks  are 
identified, CGIF staff will attempt to mitigate those financial risks satisfactorily in 
cooperation with corporate management;  

(v) 

(iii)  During this financial due diligence, CGIF must ensure that there are no corporate 
activities in the prohibited investments (para 199 of the Operational Policies); 
(iv)  During the financial due diligence and in consultation with the local counsel, the 
corporate  bank  and  the  concerned  credit  rating  agency  CGIF  must  ensure  that 
there  are  no  financial,  legal  or  reputational  risks  pending  that  could  adversely 
affect  the  debt  repayment  capacity  during  the  life  of  the  proposed  bond 
guarantee;.   
In  cooperation  with  the  client's  investment  bank  and  the  bond  pricing  agency 
(where  available),  CGIF  will  assess  the  credit  spreads  for  the  proposed 
guarantee  and  discuss  the  potential  pricing  of  the  guarantee  and  the  resulting 
rating with the issuer and the concerned credit rating agency; and   
A  financial  due  diligence  report  on  a  proposed  guarantee  must  include  the 
findings  of  the  financial  due  diligence  mission  and  its  recommendations  for 
further processing and issues for consideration by the Guarantee and Investment 
Committee.  If  found  to  be  within  acceptable  risk  parameters  by  the  Guarantee 
and Investment Committee. The report must be provided to the CEO, the CRO, 
and the External Advisory Panel. A guarantee under consideration may then be 
submitted  to  the  Board  of  Directors  and  the  External  Advisory  Panel  for  their 
consideration.

VIII.  Anti Corruption, Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing 

 Anticorruption  

In  performing  customer  due  diligence,  CGIF  assesses  the  risk  of  fraud  and  corruption 

216. 
and take measures to avoid such risk, including: 
 

(i) 

Checking of involved parties against public databases; 

(ii) 

Assessing the client’s safeguards against fraud and corruption; 

(iii)  Reviewing the underlying contractual arrangements. 

 

 

 

217.  Allegations of fraud, corruption or related misconduct (coercive, collusive and obstructive 
practices) or a lack of transparency may call for further due diligence on the part of CGIF. CGIF 
reserves the right to exclude or terminate guarantee coverage when there is finding of acts of 
fraud, corruption or other misconduct on the part of the client. Such right is incorporated into the 
legal documentation governing CGIF guarantees. 
 
218.  CGIF operations and staff are required to adhere to the highest ethical standards. Staff 
are bound by pertinent ADB rules and procedures and staff code of conduct. Violations of the 
duties  and  obligations  incumbent  on  staff  are  dealt  with  severely,  and  disciplinary  measures 
imposed accordingly. In addition, staff found to have engaged in corrupt conduct are required to 
make  full  restitution  of  any  benefits  arising  from  that  corrupt  conduct.  This  procedure  applies 
equally to situations in which staff improperly and unlawfully enrich themselves or those close to 
them, and circumstances in which they induce others to do so. 
 
Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 
 
219.  CGIF  avoids  direct  or  indirect  exposure  to  money  laundering  (ML)  and  financing  of 
terrorism (FT) by undertaking the following measures:  
 

a.  Adoption  of  international  standards  –  CGIF  operations  will  be  guided  by 
the  Financial  Action  Task  Force’s  Forty  Recommendations  and  Special 
Recommendations  on  Terrorist  Financing  (FATF  Recommendations),  in 
particular  Recommendations  4  to  22  identifying  measures  to  be  taken  by 
financial  institutions  to  prevent  money  laundering  and  terrorist  financing. 
They  require  CGIF  to  conduct  suitable  due  diligence  on  prospective 
issuers and other clients; 
 

b.  Collaboration  with  international  organizations  –  CGIF  will  cooperate  with 

the Asia/Pacific Group (APG) on ML in its operational work; 
 

c.  Strengthening  internal  controls  –  CGIF  will  monitor  and  strengthen 
procurement  and  consultant  selection,  financial  accounting  and  auditing, 
procedures, and internal systems for CGIF-supported projects.

X. 

Human Resource Policies 

 
227.  CGIF’s human resource policies are focused on recruiting and retaining highly qualified, 
internationally  competitive  staff  to  manage  the  commercial  risks  inherent  in  CGIF  operations. 
CGIF  focuses  on  providing  guarantees  within  ASEAN+3  countries  for  investment  grade 
coporations  in  order  that  they  may  avoid  currency  and  maturity  mismatches.  Because  these 
risks are high, the human resource policies cannot be compromised. The management of these 
risks is simply too important for the sustainable provision of bond guarantees that provide these 
public  goods  within  the  ASEAN+3  region  while,  at  the  same  time,  ensuring  the  commercial 
success  of  CGIF  over  the  longer  term.  CGIF  is  operated  on  internationally  competitive  terms 
with  a  high  quality  staff  that  can  manage  guarantee  operations  to  meet  both  the  public  policy 
objectives and the commercial viability objectives of CGIF. 
 
228.  Executive staff will initially be recruited through international human resource consultants, 
based upon a job description and internationally competitive salaries, but with the nationality of 
executives  restricted  to  countries  that  are  members  of  ADB.  Professional  staff  will  also  be 
recruited  internationally,  and  with  their  nationality  restricted  to  countries  that  are  members  of 
ADB. As technical skills in financial risk management are of paramount importance for CGIF’s 
success, nationality quotas will not be applied to CGIF staff. CGIF support staff will be recruited 
locally  to  minimize  costs  while  ensuring  efficient  and  effective  services.  Discrimination  on  the 
basis  of  race,  color,  gender,  age,  religion,  national  origin  within  ADB’s  membership,  and 
disability  status  is  prohibited  throughout  the  employment  process,  from  recruitment  through  to 
termination. The Trustee will be a member of all CGIF recruitment panels and will participate in 
setting  selection  standards  of  CGIF  staff.  Open  and  transparent  recruitment  and  promotion 
practices will be adhered to as the best insurance in fulfilling these human resource policies. 
 
229.  Employment  contracts  will  have  a  probationary  period  of  six  months.  Thereafter,  a 
contract  may  be  terminated  by  either  party  with  one  month’s  notice,  provided  that  CGIF  may 
provide  one  month’s  salary  in  lieu  of  30  day’s  notice.  Salary  levels  will  be  negotiated  based 
upon  internationally  competitive  levels.  While  in  CGIF  employment,  staff  will  be  extended  the 
benefits negotiated in the context of their recruitment, either internationally or locally, including 
health, education, and pension provisions through contributory schemes selected in cooperation 
with  the  employee.  Employee  benefit  plans  will  be  set  up  for  eligible  employees  either  in 
conjunction  with  ADB  or  independently  within  the  first  year  to  systemize  the  benefit 
arrangements  for  the  initial  executive  staff  negotiated  with  the  international  human  resources 
consultants to ensure that international competitive standards have been established.  
 
230.  Salary  adjustments  will  be  based  upon  the  level  of  work  ,  quality,  productivity  and 
performance in contributing to ensuring that CGIF remains financially viable and competitive in 
extending bond guarantees to ASEAN+3 investment rated corporations. Staff evaluations up to 
and including the CEO will be conducted on a 360 degree basis, in as confidential a manner as 
possible, under the leadership of the Human Resource Manager on an annual basis. 
 
231.  Staff evaluations will be based upon the agreed performance targets for each employee. 
A short list of agreed targets will be set for all employees at the beginning of each year. Where 
performance is below target at the end of the six month review, a remedied action plan will be 
instituted.  After  the  12-month  period,  an  annual  review  of  the  employee’s  performance  will  be 
indicated  in  relation  to  each  objective  set  at  the  beginning  of  the  year  in  terms  of  percent 
accomplished (including over 100%). This will lead to an overall assessment of achievement by 
the supervisor for the annual period. Only those that have an overall achievement in excess of 
100%  will  be  entitled  to  participate  in  the  bonus  pool  in  relation  to  their  base  salary  and  the

degree of over-achievement. Personnel procedures to fully define these operational approaches 
to staff evaluations will be developed within the six months by the Human Resource Director for 
approval  by  CGIF  Board  of  Directors.  CGIF  management  will  forward  the  records  of  any 
periodic evaluations in respect of the executive staff to the Trustee for information. The Trustee 
will  also  have  the  right  to  review  such  records  in  respect  of  any  professional  staff,  if  it  deems 
such review necessary. 
 
232.  A bonus pool will be set up using 10% of CGIF annual profits from operations, excluding 
investment  returns.  Bonuses  will  however  be  deferred  until  fully  realized,  that  is  until  the  last 
potential  calls  against  the  guarantees  written  in  the  applicable  year  have  expired.  Should  any 
guarantees  in  that  year  be  subject  to  a  call,  the  bonus  pool  will  be  first  in  line  to  be  used  in 
meeting any such calls. To be eligible for the bonus pool, a staff member must have been an 
employee for a full year. The annual bonus pools will be disbursed to eligible CGIF staff based 
upon an individual’s staff salary share of eligible employees’ salaries. The detailed operations of 
the  bonus  pool  will  be  proposed  by  CEO,  approved  by  CGIF  Board  of  Directors  and 
implemented within the first year. 
 
233.  Staff  training  and  skill  development  are  integral  part  of  human  resource  development. 
Each staff member is to be encouraged to engage in relevant training to ensure that skills are 
kept up to date. Staff seminars are to be encouraged on applicable topics for CGIF as part of 
ensuring the development of a learning environment at CGIF.  All staff members are expected 
to update and expand their skills relative to their employment obligations to CGIF and individual 
staff  have  an  obligation  to  attend  such  training  on  a  periodic  basis  in  line  with  the  training 
programs formulated by the Human Resource Manager. 
 
234.  The  initial  employment  contracts  will  be  developed  in  conjunction  with  international 
human resource consultants who will assist the Nomination and Remuneration Committee and 
the Trustee in recruiting and negotiating the initial salary and benefit contracts with the key initial 
staff  in  line  with  these  human  resource  principles.   Based  upon  this  experience,  the  CEO  will 
ensure  that  Board  proposals  are  initiated  for  human  resource  polices  to  meet  the  high  level 
human resource requirements of CGIF on a continuing basis.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
1.  This  project  aims  to  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  support  poverty  alleviation  regionally  in  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations, People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) and reflects a decade-
long drive toward this objective ever since the Asian financial crisis. In response to the very large poverty-creating impacts of 
the Asian crisis, ASEAN+3 governments have, with the assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) addressed the root 
causes  of  that  crisis.  One  of  those  causes  was  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  that  resulted  from  overdependence  on 
short-term foreign currency  loans for long-term investment undertaken by  corporations in ASEAN+3. Under the Asian Bond 
Market  Initiative  (ABMI),  ADB  has  actively  worked  as  the  secretariat  of  ASEAN+3  working  groups  to  determine  appropriate 
solutions for these maturity  and currency mismatches. Early and  extended efforts  went into developing local currency bond 
markets  so  that  corporations  would  not  need  to  borrow  abroad  and  encounter  currency  mismatches.  Unfortunately,  the 
alternative of borrowing from local banks resulted in maturity mismatches in which the term for investment financing is much 
greater than the term of bank loans, requiring corporations to refinance their bank loans several times over the term of their 
investments. This refinancing is very risk prone and could result in the bankruptcy of the corporation and even of the domestic 
financial  institutions,  as  occurred  during  the  Asian  crisis  with  massive  impact  on  poverty.  While  much  progress  has  been 
made  in  ASEAN+2  (ASEAN+3  minus  Japan,  whose  bond  markets  have  long  been  fully  developed)  in  developing  local 
currency  bond  markets,  investment  grade  coporations  still  did  not  have  access  to  such  markets  as  appropriate  prudential 
requirements limit financial institutions’  purchases of bonds rated below  A. In the early  stage of market development, these 
financial  institutions  are  the  principal  purchasers  of  corporate  bonds.  The  continued  risks  from  the  current  exclusion  of 
investment  grade  coporations  from  these  markets  were  highlighted  during  the  recent  international  financial  crisis,  when 
difficult  problems  were  noted  in  respect  to  these  corporations,  especially  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  and  Indonesia.  To  give 
access to corporations who have a rating of at least BBB, which is investment quality, to the local currency bond markets, this 
project will establish the Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF) as a trust fund of ADB and provide $130 million in 
equity investment to enable CGIF to issue guarantees for eligible issuers and thereby allow them to access ASEAN+3 local 
currency  bond  markets  and  avoid  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  in  financing  longer-term  investments  such  as  in  the 
infrastructure needed to reduce poverty.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                              Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues. Financial fragility has an indirect but strong link to poverty that is particularly notable during recurrent financial 
crisis,  as  occurred  in  ASEAN+3  during  the  Asian  financial  crisis  of  1997–1998  and  more  recently  during  the  international 
financial crisis of 2007–2009. Measures to improve financial resilience will make major contributions to sustainable economic 
growth and poverty alleviation in ASEAN+3.   
2.  Design  Features.  The  project  will  facilitate  investment-rated  corporations’  access  to  local  currency  bond  markets  and 
thereby avoid the currency and maturity mismatches that contributed to financial fragility and financial crises in ASEAN+3. 

C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending Not applicable 
 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Key  Issues.  The  poverty  impacts  are  indirect  in  terms  of  sustaining  growth  and  poverty  alleviation.  Nevertheless,  the 
counterfactual  of  what  would  happen  in  the  absence  of  these  measures  could  be  significant.  The  poverty  impacts  of  past 
financial crisis have been very substantial. An investment through this project in crisis prevention is highly effective in terms of 
sustaining  growth  and  alleviating  poverty  in  the  future.  There  will  also  be  significant  impact  on  corporate  and  financial 
institutions, as crisis-prevention measures will help reduce the risks of bankruptcy and consequent unemployment and other 
poverty-increasing impacts, to which lower-income groups and women are especially vulnerable.

C.   Gender and Development 

1.  Key  Issues.  In  financial  crises  characterized  by  the  bankruptcy  of  corporations  and  financial  institutions,  mass 
unemployment particularly affects the most vulnerable lower-income groups and women. Crisis prevention under this project 
will alleviate any such impacts.

Appendix 5 

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 

1. 
The  financial  analysis  of  the  Credit  Guarantee  and  Investment  Facility  (CGIF)  is  done 
entirely on a pro forma basis, as CGIF must first be approved to be formed as a trust fund of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) before it can be capitalized and operations initiated. With ADB 
Board  approval  in  the  first  half  of  2010,  the  equity  contributions  of  the  governments  of  the 
members  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations,  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC), 
Japan, and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) and ADB can be initiated at the time of the ADB 
annual meeting in May 2010. 
 
2. 
The  initial  capital  committed  at  present  is  $200  million  each  from  Japan  and  the  PRC 
and $100 million from the Republic of Korea. In addition, ASEAN countries have indicated their 
expectation  to  raise  another  $70  million  collectively.  ASEAN+3  has  asked  ADB  for  a  capital 
contribution of $130 million. In total, these indications amount to initial capital of $700 million for 
CGIF.  While  ASEAN+3  finance  ministers  have  indicated  that  additional  capital  will  be 
forthcoming as demand for bond guarantees is met by CGIF, no additional capital contributions 
have been assumed for this analysis.1 Nevertheless, simulations based upon additional capital 
only increase the financial viability of CGIF with higher rates of return. 
 
3. 
While  CGIF  will  be  publicly  owned,  it  will  be  run  on  commercial  terms  by  a  staff  of 
internationally competitive financial experts with private sector experience. CGIF guarantees will 
be  marketed  and  priced  on  market  terms.  That  is,  if  the  CGIF  guarantee  will  yield  an  interest 
rate advantage of 200 basis points, approximately 180 basis points will be retained by CGIF to 
cover  its  risks  while  the  other  20  basis  points  will  go  to  the  issuer  to  cover  their  extra  costs 
associated  with  the  financial  and  social  due  diligence  required  by  CGIF.  In  addition  to  the 
reduced  interest  rate  costs,  the  issuer  will  also  benefit,  hopefully,  from  a  maturity  extension 
made  possible  by  the  CGIF  guarantee.  In  the  financial  projections,  it  is  assumed  that  CGIF’s 
average guarantee fee will be 150 basis points, again a very conservative estimate based upon 
current  spreads  between  BBB  and  A  ratings  in  the  capital  markets  of  ASEAN+3  minus  Japan 
(ASEAN+2).  CGIF  will  be  operational,  free  to  extend  partial  or  complete  guarantees, 
conditioned as appropriate, to meet market demands.  
 
The demand for CGIF guarantees is expected to be strong for locally rated investment-
4. 
grade corporations, i.e., those rated between BBB and A and are now largely excluded from the 
local currency bond markets (for an explanation of the common credit ratings, see Appendix 6). 
Prudential requirements that protect depositors and investors generally limit banks in ASEAN+3 
to  buy  only  securities  rated  A  or  better,  while  insurance  companies  and  pension  plans  are 
generally required to buy  only securities rated AA or better. While these prudential restrictions 
are  fully  supported,  they  cause  local  currency  bond  markets  to  miss  segments  in  their  early 
development.  As  a  result,  investment  grade  corporations,  rated  between  BBB  and  A,  do  not 
generally  have  access  to  local  currency  bond  markets  in  ASEAN+2.  Based  upon  a  demand 
study  undertaken  in  ASEAN+2,  the  expected  demand  will  rise  from  $3,470  million  in  2011  to 
$5,652  million  in  2020  (Supplementary  Appendix  A).2  The  financial  modeling  for  CGIF  thus 
covers 2011–2020. 
 
5. 
Initially,  CGIF  will  be  constrained  to  use  a  leverage  ratio  of  1:1.  Other  international 
agencies  such  as  Multilateral  Investment  Guarantee  Agency  and  European  Bank  for 

                                                 
1 The joint media statement of the 12th ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ Meeting, 3 May 2009, Bali, Indonesia, page 2. 
2 The growth rate in the study for the period 2011–2016 was a conservatively estimated 6%, and it was assumed that 

the growth rate beyond 2016 to 2020 would be 5% per year. 

  

 Appendix 5 

111 

Development  and  Reconstruction  use  leverage  ratios  in  the  1:4–8  range  while  the  monoline 
agencies  in  the  United  States  generally  have  leverage  ratios  in  the  neighborhood  of  1:50  and 
above.  When  CGIF  is  successfully  set  up  in  2010  and  begins  to  meet  demand  for  bond 
guarantees in  ASEAN+2,  CGIF  can  approach the  meeting  of  contributors  to  raise its  leverage 
ratio.  However,  any  guarantees  above  1:1  will  be  reinsured  so  that  the  residual  financial 
obligations with CGIF will still not be greater than 1:1. As such, neither ADB nor the ASEAN+3 
governments  will  ever  face  the need  to  meet  guarantee  or  other  CGIF  obligations,  as  there  is 
also a prohibition against CGIF borrowing for operations.  
 
6. 
The financial statements for CGIF have been conservatively modeled and are shown as 
a  simplified  cash  flow  statement  and  an  equally  simplified  income  statement.  The  pro  forma 
balance  sheet  is  not  shown  as  it  consists  primarily  of  two  entries,  namely,  the  shareholders 
equity  and  the  corresponding  assets  invested  to  meet  any  potential  calls  from  the  guaranteed 
bonds, as the bond guarantees extended by CGIF are contingent liabilities that are recorded in 
notes  to  the  balance  sheet.  The  base  case  financial statements  are shown  in  Table  A5.1  (the 
simplified cash flow analysis) and Table A5.2 (the simplified income statement). All guaranteed 
bonds  are  assumed  to  be  $50  million  with  5-year  bullet  maturities.  All  guarantee  fees  are 
collected  up  front.  No  calls  are  assumed  in  the  base  case  scenario,  although  stress  test 
summaries  are  detailed  below.  The  estimated  terminal  value  of  CGIF  is  assumed  to  be  1.5 
times net asset value in 2020 for the purposes of this financial projection. 
 
7. 
As shown in the base case scenario in Tables A5.1 and A5.2, CGIF is expected to begin 
operations  in  2011  and  meet  only  about  3%  of  the  indicated  demand  due  to  initial  capital 
constraints.  However,  the  capital  constraint  assumed  for  CGIF  under  this  base  scenario  also 
means that CGIF will not need to expand beyond its initial pilot level of staffing (estimated at 23, 
as shown in Table A5.2). The internal rate of return (IRR) for CGIF is 6.8%, almost double the 
return on 10-year US government bonds that would be the equivalent AAA rating. Of course, the 
real returns are those that serve the public policy objectives of reducing financial fragility in the 
ASEAN+3  region  by  eliminating  currency  and  maturity  mismatches  for  those  corporations 
whose  bonds  have  been  guaranteed  by  CGIF  to  allow  access  to  local  currency-denominated 
bond markets. 
  
CGIF  operations  are  extraordinarily  resilient  to  financial  shocks.  For  example,  if 
8. 
economic dislocation is assumed in one economy with a 10% failure rate for CGIF-guaranteed 
bonds, the resulting loss would be $44 million in 2016, as shown in Tables A5.3 and A5.4. This 
assumed failure rate is over 20 times the expected level.3 No recoveries are assumed. Yet, this 
massive failure reduces the IRR rather little to 5.8% from 6.8% in the base case.  
 
9. 
Still more stringent stress tests are possible through assuming an economic depression 
from  2014  to  2017,  during  which  5%  default  loss  in  each  of  the  four  years  is  assumed.  In 
addition,  no  new  guarantees  are  extended  during  the  depression  years.  As  shown  in  Tables 
A5.5  and  A5.6,  CGIF  reports  losses  in  these  years.  However,  the  IRR  for  the  entire  period  is 
nevertheless  positive  at  4.8%,  albeit  down  from  6.8%  in  the  base  case.  In  all  cases,  CGIF 
returns are still higher than the current 10-year US Treasury bond at 3.8%. CGIF is resilient to 
any potential financial shocks.  

                                                 
3 The  average  default  rate  on  BBB  bonds  globally  is  0.28%,  as  calculated  by  Standard  and  Poor’s  over  the  period 

from 1981 to 2008.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS—EVOLUTION OF REGIONAL BOND MARKET1 

Background 

 
A. 
 
In  1997,  at  the  time  of  the  Asian  financial  crisis,  local  currency  bond  markets  in  most 
1. 
members  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  plus  the  People’s  Republic  of  China 
(PRC) and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+2) were underdeveloped, and options for borrowers 
were  therefore  limited.  Bank  lending  was  a  primary  source  of  credit,  but  such  credit  was 
commonly  short  term,  less  than  3  years.  For  larger  borrowers  and  in  particular  infrastructure 
investors,  such  short-term  loans  posed  a  refinancing  risk,  which  is  the  risk  that  lenders  would 
not  renew  their  credit.  For  larger,  long-term  investors,  an  alternative  was  to  borrow 
internationally,  but  such  borrowing  involved  foreign  exchange  risk,  the  risk  that  their  domestic 
currency would depreciate relative to the currency in which they had borrowed. These currency 
and  maturity  mismatches  faced  investors  in  1997  and  1998  and  are  now  widely  seen  as 
contributing to the severity of the Asian crisis.  
 
To  address  some  of  the  root  causes  of  the  crisis,  ensure  the  availability  of  long-term 
2. 
domestic currency funding, and channel the region’s savings into regional investment, individual 
countries of ASEAN+2 have undertaken massive financial sector reform, including restructuring 
balance  sheets  to  dispose  of  nonperforming  loans,  overhauling  bank  ownership,  privatizing 
many state-owned institutions, upgrading macro-prudential oversight via revamped regulations 
and supervision, and introducing new products and businesses. 
 
3. 
In addition, East Asia’s policy makers have worked together to promote and develop a 
regional  bond  market.  In  December  2002,  the  finance  ministers  of  ASEAN+3,  which  is 
ASEAN+2  plus  Japan,  launched  the  Asian  Bond  Markets  Initiative  (ABMI)  to  promote  the 
development  of  local  currency  bond  markets.  Another  regional  initiative  to  support  the 
development of local currency bond markets is the Asian Bond Fund, launched by Asian central 
banks through the Executives’ Meeting of East Asia–Pacific Central Banks in June 2003.  
 
B. 
 
Under the ABMI, ASEAN+3 policy makers aimed to develop both primary and secondary 
4. 
bond markets by (i) building sufficient sovereign bond issuance to establish market benchmarks; 
(ii) constructing an effective regulatory environment for the region’s financial institutions to issue 
bonds  to  meet  their  financing  requirements;  (iii) creating  markets  for  asset-backed  securities 
and  other  relatively  new  products;  (iv) increasing  issuance  by  multilateral  development  banks 
and government agencies; (v) promoting issuance for funding foreign investment, particularly in 
infrastructure; and (vi) expanding local currency bonds and introducing currency basket bonds.  
 
ASEAN+3 has focused on four areas viewed as the basic, essential building blocks for 
5. 
developing  bond  markets:  (i)  creating  new  securitized  debt  instruments;  (ii) establishing  a 
regional credit guarantee and investment mechanism; (iii) establishing a regional settlement and 
clearance  system;  and  (iv) enhancing  credit  rating.  The  purpose  has  been  to  (i) create  larger 
volumes of new bond issues denominated in Asian currencies by the private sector; (ii) improve 
credit information on debt issuers in the region to facilitate investment decisions; and (iii) build 
market infrastructure to support cross-border issuance and investment. All these activities have 
been  supported  regionally  and  financed  by  the  governments  of  Japan,  the  Republic  of  Korea, 
and the PRC. In addition, to complete activities supported under the ABMI, the Government of 
Japan  has  provided  technical  assistance  to  individual  countries  to  address  constraints  on  the 
development of bond markets. 

Asian Bond Market Initiative 

 120 
 

Appendix 7 

 
6. 
To  demonstrate  their  renewed  and  strong  commitment  to  bond  market  development, 
ASEAN+3  worked  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  develop  a  medium-term  road 
map  in  2008  to  accelerate  the  development  of  the  regional  bond  market.  The  road  map  is 
consistent with the Group of Eight 8 action plan to support the development of local currency 
bond  markets.  The  road  map  draws  on  the  progress  achieved  under  ABMI  and  reforms 
undertaken  by  member  countries  to  promote  bond  market  development.  The  road  map 
expanded from measures to build a basic and essential foundation for markets to the measures 
required for improving the efficiency, transparency, and liquidity of the markets. 
 
7. 
The  road  map  entails,  among  other  things,  ASEAN+3  and  ADB  support  to  (i) develop 
derivatives  and  swap  markets,  as  well  as  repo  markets;  (ii) broaden  the  investor  base; 
(iii) address  policy  impediments  to  cross-border  transactions;  (iv) strengthen  the  legal  and 
regulatory  framework  for  bond  markets;  (v) improve  transparency  in  the  markets;  and 
(vi) develop the professional services required for the development of bond markets. ASEAN+3 
has  also  agreed  to  take  concrete  steps  under  the  road  map  to  improve  cross-border 
transactions with the establishment of a regional credit guarantee facility to improve access to 
debt  markets  for  issuers  and  undertake  a  feasibility  study  for  the  establishment  of  a  regional 
settlement  intermediary  for  cross-border  settlement  and  clearance.  Activities  under  each  key 
area  are  undertaken  by  a  task  force  co-chaired  by  two  member  countries  of  ASEAN+3,  with 
ADB as the secretariat. The steering group has been established to monitor and coordinate the 
activities of the task force. 
 
8. 
To advance the development of the regional bond market in a concerted manner, each 
member of ASEAN+3 periodically assesses its own progress in developing the bond market in 
its own country. Lastly, given the importance of the private sector in developing bond markets, 
ASEAN+3  has  welcomed  and  encouraged  private  sector  participation  in  the  policy  discussion 
relating to cross-border bond transactions and settlement issues. 
 
C. 
 
9. 
The domestic reforms and collective regional efforts are gradually having an impact on 
the  development  of  bond  markets.  Emerging  East  Asian  local  currency  (LCY)  markets  have 
emerged  as  an  important  source  of  funding  for  both  regional  governments  and  companies 
during  the  recent  financial  market  turmoil.  While  it  was  difficult  to  raise  long-term  debt  in  US 
dollars during the recent financial turmoil, local companies have aggressively tapped domestic 
bond markets to raise new funds and refinance, pushing corporate LCY bond issuance to record 
levels  in  some  emerging  East  Asian  markets.  Governments  in  the  region  have  also  turned  to 
LCY  bond  markets  to  finance  fiscal  stimulus  to  counter  the  impact  of  weak  external  demand. 
Total bonds outstanding in emerging East Asian LCY bond markets grew by 14% year on year 
on an LCY basis in the third quarter of 2009 to $4.2 trillion. This represents an average growth 
rate of 19% since 2002.  
 
10. 
The ratio of emerging East Asian LCY bonds outstanding to the region’s gross domestic 
product rose to 62% at the end of the third quarter of 2009 from 58% in the previous quarter. 
The three markets with the most significant increase in their ratio of total LCY bonds outstanding 
to  gross  domestic  product  were  the  Republic  of  Korea  (12  percentage  points);  Singapore  (8 
percentage points); and Hong Kong, China (8 percentage points).  
 
11. 
Table A7.1 presents data on emerging East Asia’s share of the world bond market, 
which  grew  to  6.2%  at  the  end  of  2008  from  2%  at  the  end  of  1996.  Table  A7.2 

Recent Developments in Local Currency Market in Emerging Asia 

  

  

Appendix 7 
Appendix 4 

121 
121 

disaggregates  this  amount  by  bonds  issued  by  emerging  East  Asian  governments, 
financial  institutions,  and  nonfinancial  corporations.  Governments  in  emerging  East  Asia 
account  for  a  proportionally  larger  amount  of  the  region’s  LCY  bonds  outstanding—that  is, 
7.2%  of  global  government  bonds  outstanding—compared  with  6.2%  of  total  global  bonds 
outstanding  for  emerging  East  Asian  bond  issuers.  In  this  sense,  emerging  East  Asia’s 
financial institutions account for a smaller share (4.3%) of the global total of such bonds, 
while nonfinancial corporations’ account for a much larger share (8.3%).

12. 
The  principal  driver  behind  emerging  East  Asia’s  proportionally  larger  share  of 
government  bonds  is  the  PRC.  The  global  shares  of  the  PRC’s  financial  institution  and 
corporate  bond  sectors  are  only  about  half  as  large  as  the  global  share  of  PRC 
government securities. However, the global share of the financial institution and corporate 
bond sectors is rising rapidly and may become dominant players in coming years. 
 
13.  When looking at emerging East Asia excluding the PRC, the structural composition 
changes dramatically. Emerging East Asian bonds outstanding excluding the PRC account 
for 2.5% of global bonds outstanding. The government sector’s share of global government 
bonds  outstanding  is  about  the  same,  at  2.4%,  while  the  financial  sector’s  share  is 
proportionally  smaller  (1.7%)  and  the  corporate  sector’s  share  is  proportionally  larger 
(5.5%). 
 
The major factor behind this result is the Republic of Korea’s bond market. Although 
14. 
its share of the global bond market is only 1.3%, or roughly about the same as Brazil’s, its 
share  of  the  nonfinancial  corporate  sector  is  3.3%.  This  reflects  issuance  by  both  the 
Republic of Korea’s nonfinancial private corporate sector and even larger bond issuance by 

 122 
 

Appendix 7 

the  state-owned  corporate  sector  and  a  number  of  transportation  and  infrastructure 
companies.  In  fact,  bonds  issued  by  publicly  owned,  nonfinancial  corporations  account  for 
around 55% of the bonds issued by nonfinancial corporations in the Republic of Korea. 
 
One distinguishing feature of the emerging East Asian bond market’s performance was 
15. 
strong  growth  in  bond  markets  outside  of  the  PRC.  The  emerging  East  Asian  bond  market, 
excluding the PRC, grew 16.0% year on year. Meanwhile, the PRC’s bond market growth rate 
was 13.9% year on year in the third quarter of 2009.

Structure of Emerging East Asian Corporate Bond Markets

D. 
 
16. 
State-owned  enterprises  remain  the  dominant  players  in  many  of  the  region’s  LCY 
corporate  bond  markets.  Although  the  overall  trend  is  toward  privatization,  state-owned 
companies  are  still  dominant  in  many  countries  and  are  often  the  largest  issuers  in  individual 
corporate bond markets.  
 
17. 
Thus,  the  Asian  corporate  bond  market  primarily  consists  of  government-owned 
companies and financial institutions. This is different from the Western concept of a corporation 
as  a  privately  owned,  nonfinancial  company.  Such  entities  comprise  a  relatively  small  part  of 
most Asian corporate bond markets. 
 
In  the  case  of  the  Republic  of  Korea,  privately  owned  nonfinancial  corporations,  as 
18. 
defined  above,  account  for  only  23%  of  bonds  classified  as  corporate when  determining  bond 
market  size  and  composition.  Banks  and  nonbank  financial  institutions  account  for  more  than 
50% of corporate bonds outstanding in the Republic of Korea. 
 
19. 
The  major  share  of  corporate  sector  issuance  in  the  PRC  is  from  the  public  sector. 
Government-linked  companies  are also  prominent  issuers  in  Singapore  and  in  the more  liquid 

  

  

Appendix 7 
Appendix 4 

123 
123 

portion  of  the  Hong  Kong,  China  corporate  bond  market,  where  the  government-owned  Hong 
Kong  Mortgage  Corporation,  Airport  Authority,  and  Urban  Renewal  Authority  are  important 
issuers. 
 
Private  companies  account  for  a  larger  share  of  the  corporate  bond  market  in  the 
20. 
Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia, but state-owned power and energy companies 
are also important issuers in these markets. 
 
Most  of  the  outstanding  corporate  bond  stock  in  Asia  is  concentrated  in  three  major 
21. 
sectors:  banking,  infrastructure,  and  energy.  A  substantial  portion  of  the  region’s  bank  bond 
issuance has been in the form of tier 2 (subordinated debt) securities, which are quasi-equity 
instruments  that  can  be  counted  as  part  of  regulatory  capital.  Banks  have  been  issuing 
subordinated debt bonds (sub debt) to maintain capital adequacy ratios (CARs) at acceptable 
levels,  as  they  have  accelerated  their  lending  activities  in  sync  with  government  economic 
stimulus programs. In particular, banks in the PRC have been issuing very large amounts of 
subordinated debt bonds to bolster their CARs. This is true in most other markets as well. In 
addition  to  issuing  bonds  to  improve  capital  adequacy,  banks  have  been  issuing  bonds  for 
funding purposes as well. 
 
22. 
The  importance  of  energy-  and  infrastructure-related  issuers  explains  the  continued 
significance  of  state-owned  companies  as  issuers  in  the  corporate  bond  market.  The  highest 
concentration of infrastructure-related companies can be seen in the Malaysian market, where 
the  large  volume  of  infrastructure  companies’  bonds  outstanding  reflects  their  role  in  overall 
economic growth. 
 
23. 
The domination of the corporate bond market by the infrastructure and energy sectors is 
probably most pronounced in the PRC, where infrastructure and energy companies represent a 
significant portion of issuance in several categories of the corporate bond market (e.g., medium-
term notes, state-owned enterprise bonds, and commercial paper). 
 
E. 
 
The  maturity  structure  in  most  emerging  East  Asian  bond  markets—defined  as  debt 
24. 
securities  with  maturities  exceeding  1  year—favors  the  shorter  end  of  the  profile  in  most 
markets. In emerging East Asia’s government bond markets, maturities have been concentrated 
at the shorter end of the curve (1–3 years), especially in Hong Kong, China; Viet Nam; and the 
Republic  of  Korea.  These  three  markets,  as  well  as  the  Philippine  bond  market,  have  10%  or 
less  of  their  bonds  outstanding  in  maturities  of  more  than  10  years.  Indonesia,  on  the  other 
hand, has the maturity structure with the heaviest concentration of maturities at the long end of 
the curve (more than 10 years). Other markets have concentrated their maturities in the ranges 
of 3–5 and 5–10 years.  
 
25. 
The  maturity  structures  of  the  PRC  and  Singapore  markets  are  more  balanced  than  in 
most other markets at present, with a larger portion of their bonds in maturities of more than 10 
years and a substantial portion of maturities in the range of 5–10 years. The Philippine maturity 
profile  has  the  heaviest  concentration  of  maturities  in  the  range  of  5–10  years,  reflecting  a 
traditional preference for issuing 10-year maturities. More recently, however, the Government of 
the  Philippines  has  begun  to  issue  more  longer-dated  maturities.  Finally,  Asian  governments 
and central banks generally reduced their proportion of bills (maturities of less than 1 year) to 
bonds in the third quarter of 2009. Only Singapore; the PRC; and Hong Kong, China increased 
their ratios of bills to bonds in that quarter. 

Maturity Profile

F. 
 
26.  More needs to be done to give corporations better access to the region’s bond markets 
and  to  offer  a  variety  of  maturities  to  meet  issuers’  financing  needs.  For  example,  regulators 
normally  prescribe  minimum  ratings  for  bond  investments  for  the  companies  they  supervise, 
generally  A  for  banks  and  AA  for  insurance  companies,  or  in  some  cases  limit  the  portfolio 
exposure  of  the  insurance  companies  to  a  certain  percentage.  Moreover,  there  is  a  deeper 
affinity  for  investment  in  equity  markets  among  domestic  investors  than  in  bond  markets  as 
corporate bonds are relatively new investment in emerging Asia.  
 
27. 
The spread between bonds rated AAA and BBB is used as an indicator of credit quality 
spread,  because  it  indicates  how  much  of  a  premium  investors  demand  for  holding  riskier 
corporate assets among the four markets analyzed (Figure 1).

28. 
The credit quality spreads for Malaysia are the highest among the four markets analyzed, 
and the short end of the curve rose above end-December levels at the end of June 2009. The 
short  end  of  the  Malaysian  curve  at  the  end  of  June  2009  was,  in  fact,  at  its  highest  since 
September 2008. 
 
29. 
For  the  PRC,  spreads are  available  dating  back  only  to  the  beginning  of  the  year,  and 
they have fallen along the entire length of the PRC credit quality curve but still range above 400 
basis points for most of the curve.

In  the  Republic  of  Korea,  the  credit  quality  spread  has  risen  significantly  over  the  past

32. 
In Malaysia, a local bond guarantor, Danajamin, was recently established. More broadly, 
local bond guarantors are lacking to enhance investment-grade companies ratings from BBB to 
at least A, if not AA. Limited access to bond markets poses particular problems for corporations 
with long-term financing needs, such as for infrastructure investments that generally have a life 
span of 15–20 years and from which revenues are generally in local currency. One alternative 
has  been  bank  financing.  But  loans  seldom  extend  beyond  3  years,  posing  refinancing  risks 
throughout  the  life  of  the  project.  A  second  alternative  has  been  overseas  financing.  But  this 
gives rise to foreign exchange risk. It is the policy goal of ASEAN+3 to establish CGIF to help 
improve corporations’ access to LCY bond markets.

B.  Environmental and Social Management System Policy 
 
2. 
As  part  of  the  process of  establishing  and  operationalizing the  ESMS,  CGIF  will  prepare 
and  adopt  an  environmental  and  social  safeguard  policy  statement  to  the  effect  that  it  will  (i) 
actively  encourage  and  require  its  clients  to  adhere  to  applicable  environmental  and  social 
safeguard  requirements  that  it  subscribes  to  and,  (ii)  where  the  client's  relevant  business 
activities contravene applicable environmental and social safeguards, take action to understand 
the reasons for noncompliance and discuss with the client corrective actions acceptable to ADB 
and government authorities.

C.  Environmental and Social Management System Procedure 
 
3. 
Before  providing  any  guarantee  to  a  client, the guarantee  and  investment  committee  will 
undertake  the  following  steps  to  ensure  that  client's  investment  complies  with  the  applicable 
environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples  safeguard  policies of  ADB  and 
the government(s) of the concerned ASEAN+3 member country or countries. 
 

1.  Due Diligence and Review 

 

Reviewers will do the following: 

4. 
 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 

Screen the proposed investment to ensure that it is not included in ADB’s list of 
prohibited investment activities.   
Classify  the  investment  according  to  the  significance  of  potential  environmental 
and social impacts using ADB's project classification criteria.1 
For investments classified as category A or B, or those with potentially adverse 
environmental  and  social  impacts,  review  the  environmental  and/or  social 
assessment  reports  including  safeguard  plans  (e.g.,  the  initial  environmental 
examination  or  environmental  impact  assessment,  including  the  environmental 
management,  resettlement,  and/or  indigenous  people’s  development  plans 
prepared for the proposed investment) to ensure they meet government and ADB 
requirements.2  
Ensure that clients disclose information relevant to the environmental and social 
impacts of investments and consult with project-affected people at an early stage 
of project preparation, so that their views are taken into account. The guarantee 
and  investment  committee  will  ensure  that  ADB  and  government  information 
disclosure and consultation requirements are complied with.   
Visit the site as required to review the adequacy of safeguard plans as applicable 
and the estimate cost of plan implement. If there are gaps, discuss with the client 
targeted and time-bound actions to address them.   
For investments involving an existing facility with potential adverse environmental 
and  social  impacts  (category  A  or  B  from  the  environmental,  involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous people’s perspectives), visit the site as required to 
conduct audits to identify compliance gaps. If any are found, agree with the client 
on  the  preparation  of  a  corrective  action  plan  with  a  budget  and  timeline  for 
implementation.  Also  review  the  client's  compliance  with  applicable  government 
laws,  regulations,  and  requirements  (e.g.,  receipt  of  environmental  clearance, 
permits, and approvals; consent to establish; consent to operate; etc.) and verify 
that  the  client  has  no  claims  pending  against  it  in  connection  with  a  liability  
related to an environmental or social safeguard. 
For  investments  with  potentially  adverse  environmental  and/or  social  impacts 
(category  A  or  B  from  the  environmental,  involuntary  resettlement,  and 
indigenous people’s perspectives), if CGIF is not able to reasonably satisfy itself 
that the relevant business activities of the client comply with applicable ADB and
